author: {'steamid': '76561197988257417', 'num_games_owned': 1691, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1583905558}
review:
It's cute but very simplistic and the strategic layer is not very deep. I would not bother with this as there are much better titles in its kind.

PROS

- Cute art
- Simple and playable single handed, nice for when having launch or eating (should be a mobile game really)
- The fact that it is short to complete alevitates the fact that it is so simple, it doesn't overstay its welcome and ends just about when you're bored of it

CONS

- Lack of attention to details, it is often hard to click something because your hero or a monster is sitting on it or in front of it and blocking your click
- It surprises you with level ending, while you haven't done all the rooms... at first it's a very specific door, but other missions end when you kill a monster or click on an item, for this reason it's hard to know what is gonna make it end and you do miss loot because of that
- What characters and abilities are best is very obvious and there is not much variety in what heroes you pick because you do need your tank, your healer, and your magic damage, so the choices are too obvious
- Same thing with skills, the good ones are very far and above the others so you don't really strategize as much as just pick the obvious efficient skills

author: {'steamid': '76561198033982035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 886, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1584399560}

review: A very fun game with simple turn based mechanics and just enough tactical decisions to keep you going.  A steal at the current 4.79 sale price but also worth the 7.99 if you like these types of games.  A very pleasant diversion from other more complex games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988534641', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 2378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1698554921}
review:
It's not often do you find a computer game that can function well as both a video game and a table top dungeon crawler.  It's turn base mechanics are pretty simple, you get moves and abilities based off of Golden Axe Potions you find.  (Ok, well they look like the magic potions from Golden Axe) and you got yourself a grand ol time hacking and slashing green skinned freaks.

Each class has something to offer beyond their more obvious roles... Warrior is tanky and loves to do high damage, where as the Dwarf is tanky but loves to disable traps, Archer is high damage but good on utility like the dwarf...the Knight is tanky but can heal... the Monk kills everything and the Wizard... Wizard's stuff... and sometimes makes obscene balloon animals (not really).

Though...the campaign itself seems short with a tight curve on difficulty in some respects - the game shines really bright on 2 aspects.  Yes you can replay levels but each successful time ups the difficulty...and you can play custom maps that add to your "Phat Lewt" as you cool kids would say.  (No? Kids don't say that anymore!?)

Though while some custom maps are great... others are just straight awful - but that's the blessing and curse of user generated content.

Overall I'd say it's a fun lil romp though personally I'm curious about actually playing this with a couple of friends and seeing how well this translates to multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023295634', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1574105776}
review:
Tried playing it with one friend and the game is broken and you cant win it with just two players. The last maps are.. badly designed when it comes to coop unless you have all characters with you. 
Game mechanics are disabled in multiplayer, such as all the artifacts. Because they were bugged, and a year or more later it hasn't been fixed. I guess the Disable button is easier to find.

The game were fun until that last two maps where you cant win with two players, unless you cheese it and run past all enemies and traps. If they fix the multiplayer I'd really recommend the game, but now nope.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000368827', 'num_games_owned': 1253, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1582477005}
review:
This game may be deep in terms of the amount of stuff you can unlock, I wouldn't know. Unfortunately, the moment-to-moment core gameplay is quite boring and repetitive, and I found myself very quickly losing interest. 

This game is supposedly inspired by Hero Quest, but I fear it did not understand that most of the enjoyment in HQ came from the imagination of the players; while the board may have been sparse, the description of the mission, the presence of Zargon and the implication of actual space made up for a lot in the board game. In this game, however, the rooms are almost entirely empty in terms of setting, at least at the beginning.

review:
Ce jeu m‚Äô√©voque Donjons and Dragons, bo√Æte rouge d‚Äôil y a quarante ans. Ce n‚Äôest pas fonci√®rement mauvais, c‚Äôest caricatural et‚Ä¶ rigide.
Caricatural comme peu profond, pas simple (la simplicit√© est une qualit√© √† mon sens), plut√¥t fig√© dans des certitudes d‚Äôun autre temps.
Rigide comme les animations qui ne font pas r√™ver. √Ä titre personnel, je pr√©f√®re le parti pris du carton de Cardhunter.
Mais √ßa se laisse jouer de temps √† autre, par nostalgie, pourquoi pas.
Au rayon curiosit√©¬†:
1. les attaques dans le dos ou sur le c√¥t√© n‚Äôont pas d‚Äôincidence sur les chances de toucher ou alors ce n‚Äôest mentionn√© nulle part, or il s‚Äôagit l√† d‚Äôun passage oblig√© de ce type de jeu qui singe le jeu de r√¥le. De plus, cela am√©liorerait l‚Äôaspect tactique du jeu.
2. en parlant de nulle part, il n‚Äôexiste pas livret du joueur, nous devons tout apprendre en exp√©rimentant¬†; le tutoriel de d√©but est sommaire.
3. ne pas pouvoir √©changer une ou des potions est totalement irr√©aliste.
4. n‚Äôavoir qu‚Äôune sortie possible √† chaque donjon est ridicule puisqu‚Äôon est bien entr√© quelque part
5. devoir sortir ses personnages un √† un m√™me quand on a explor√© toute une salle est fastidieux et profond√©ment barbant.
Je ne fais pas souvent √ßa mais pour le prix, avec un peu d‚Äôindulgence, √ßa se tente. √áa n‚Äôest pas passionnant, √ßa reste divertissant pour peu qu‚Äôon appr√©cie le tour par tour (semi-)tactique.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000000375', 'num_games_owned': 4080, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1578260210}
review: Needs a little work. Pathing for your characters and enemies is weird. Enemies will only attack what is closest to them, not what is most strategic. If your character is blocking a square, it's frustrating to click around it. Starts off fun, but gets tedious. Replaying the maps gets really hard really quick. Once you get all the items and skills there is nothing else to keep the momentum going.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992765686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1577924799}
review:
I really enjoyed this. It's a fairly simple turn based dungeon crawler, with Dungeons & Dragons / Sword and Sorcery roots. 

The game is a little grindy, but I enjoyed that aspect of it. Theres some decent replayability.

The draw backs are that navigation can get a little tedious. I wish there was a group travel option to make movement through explored/non-threatening rooms faster. The game could also use just a tad more tactical weight- make flanking matter, make facing matter. 

Otherwise, great game. I recommend, especially for the price. I'll buy a 3 game for sure.

review: Love it, very atmospheric, worth every penny!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032729422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1845, 'last_played': 1577737242}
review:
Not a massive game but worth picking up and playing as a ‚Äúfiller‚Äù although it may be best to wait for a sale to pick it up but it's pretty cheap anyway.

This is much improved over Dark Quest 1.  The character roster has been increased from the 3 in the original game to 6 and the range of monsters has likewise seen an increase.  The graphics have also been markedly improved and now work on an isometric system rather than the plain ‚Äútop down‚Äù view of the original.

There are also a few Steam Achievements and Virtual Trading Cards / Badge for those interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030605800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1577427412}
review: I didn't really like it at first, as it's basically just a VERY stripped-down RPG.  However, I found it's perfect to play when I'm at work, as it doesn't overheat my laptop while it's running, and its 100% turn-based nature means I don't have to pause or anything in order to take care of work stuff, so I can just return to it at my leisure.  Also, the lack of any real plot or questing, just simple dungeon-crawling levels, and it's simplicity, means if I don't play for a while, when I come back, I don't have to refamiliarize myself with what's going on in the game and its mechanics.  I can just drop back in as if I'd just played yesterday.  Basically, this game has its place, and it suits it well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962207750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1578763677}
review:
- Yes it's simple

- Yes there is a version for phones

But that doesn't mean it's not fun. On the phone version there is no online co-op, so that's a major difference.

And the simplicity was a huge part of the appeal of the original Dark Quest. It's just here it's gone isometric and has character models, where before it was top down tiles.

It's more elaborate, but it's still inspired by a tabletop for ages 9 to adult. So that means it's not like these huge RPG's with endless stuff to learn.

If you're young, you can just get on and enjoy. And if not, this is something for when you're not wanting to go to the effort of quick real-time reactions, or anything too stressful. This is one that can just be played for a quick quest or two at a time, not endless massive sessions to take over your whole life.

It's a little resource management, finding then remembering where the exit was, grabbing loot, managing combat, levelling up... rinse and repeat.

One can tut at spelling errors or the occasional clunk like needing to move a character out of the way to do something with another, or reveal the tile you want to action. But none of that is really that important in a casual experience like this, where the emphasis is on simple enjoyment;

Bottom line: Unpretentious fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198971471182', 'num_games_owned': 99, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1615563954}
review:
***This review was updated on Sept 14th 2020***
I have more than 15 hours of gameplay at this moment.

This is a nice strategic RPG game. Very faithful to the original HeroQuest boardgame from Milton Bradley in 1991. Perfect for anybody who is feeling nostalic and is wishing for a great old school RPG experience. Fans of Final Fantasy Tactics, Arc The Lad, Dragon Quest, Fire Emblem might enjoy !! Anyone who is craving for a boardgame RPG experience should try this game.

However, I would like to point out that when you want to play multiplayer mode, you will actually succeed with 3 players co-op, but 2 players co-op is insufficient to have the upper hand on the monsters in the dungeon - - you will be defeated in no time. The developers should pay attention to this.

I want to add that with their beautiful effort, I am actually very excited about their upcoming DarkQuest Boardgame on Steam. I'll get my hands on it as soon as it comes out - I promise.

In the meantime, you may want to take a look at the mobile games ''Arcane Quest 1 / 2 / 3''.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155450601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1602383408}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044653396', 'num_games_owned': 714, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1575526118}
review:
I beat the game in normal mode.
7/10

It's a dungeon crawler kind of game with simple rooms to navigate until you reach the end or complete a simple objective.

The game is a bit basic and there isn't much depth to the skills, items, or story.
It feels like it could have been developed for mobile phones.
However, I did enjoy the time I spent beating the game (over 13 hours), and that alone is worth the sale price.

The graphics are pretty good but not 'amazing'.
The sound effects are basic but efficient.
The music is actually quite good.

I would recommend this game on sale but not full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035182410', 'num_games_owned': 1144, 'num_reviews': 372, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1574769974}
review:
It's ok. 

It has some issues though. It's almost impossible to move on the tile behind an allied character as that will always result in you selecting them instead. 

There is a lot of backtracking through empty rooms in the game, yet you always have to order all 3 heroes to the room exit each time. There needed to be a "move all units" button. Because it gets tedious after a while.

Also I found a bug that if you leave a room with a possessed enemy then you are permanently stuck as the rest of your team can't actually leave the room afterwards. 

Lastly the game relies to much on chances for my liking. Each character has an attack chance and defense chance (mostly 60%) so fights often devolve into miss - miss - block - block - miss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116376659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1572756189}
review:
Purchased the game for around $2 during a sale. This is a reasonable purchasing price for a game that has potential, but lacks in any noticeable department.

*Interface/Controls
The game lacks a surprising amount of explanation for what its UI elements are, and how to use them. The options menu is adequate but you will not find any help. Learning how to equip items, how to upgrade, and more importantly, the movement of characters in the game is very difficult. You will spend much time pixel hunting, trying to move characters to specific parts of the map, simply because another characters model obscures it. There are no hotkeys to cycle through your heroes, levels end without prompting once objectives are met (despite rewarding exploration). You cannot change the camera  angle, as the games camera is fixed and the map is isometric, compounding the pixel hunting issue. 

*Gameplay loop
The primary objective of the game is to loot as much gold as possible while finishing the quest objectives with at least one hero alive. Unless you actively choose the hardest difficulty, death is only a temporary set back. There is no positive reward for killing an entire room of enemies unless it holds an objective. The rare moments enemies actually drop gold are a pitiful 10-20, while healing is the true precious commodity, the cheapest potion costing 120, and generic rests between quests costing 50 gold per hero, regardless of how much health is needed. Though exploration is pivotal to game progress, your tools are aggravating. Each individual hero (regardless of room clear) must traverse the length of the room to the exit.

In dungeons of 10-15 plus rooms, each encompassing roughly 5-10 squares of mandatory walking animation (even on fast setting) is a great bulk of game time. It boggles the mind that in general exploring heroes cannot be condensed into one square (one model representing the party). Exploring the dungeons does not become an engaging risk vs reward asset, but a tedious slog where players who've already played the game will know the optimal route. Of course, even completing a quest does not allow you to keep said map, forcing those who value their time to write it down or else wonder lost in the dungeons. As the core aspect of a dungeon-crawling adventure, the crawl is too literal.

On to more positive aspects, the combat is at least serviceable, though leaves many questions. Each hero holds unique playstyles and abilities, with minor overlap.  During your quests however, again killing enemies are generally useless. Avoiding combat for new players is my recommendation, as well as learning when it is better to take the loss and retreat or allow a party wipe (reviving dead heroes can be cheaper than individual heals). To progress in actual power, acquiring blue potions (I don't recall the true name) will allow your characters to improve their abilities, as well as gold being needed to buy equipment, all of which must be searched out in the dungeon. Both gold and blue potions are "farmable" if you find the correct map. (In the late game I prefer "Executioner" personally) Out of the 6 total heroes only 3 are allowed per quest, which is questionable, leaving the rest of the heroes useless once you enter mid game (unless you wish to farm). 

The enemies are varied enough themselves to not feel too samey, though you will recognize a pattern.  Goblins  have traps. arrows, and deadly spells, Orcs have support magic, high stats, and more bosses. Chaos, as the name implies, takes a bit of both. Beefier units, deadly unblockable spells, and magic that both supports their units and causes chaos for you the player. The game is mercifully short enough that by the time you get tired of a certain enemy type, you should be eased into the next. 

*Other features
The game boasts a dungeon editor, as well as multiplayer support. These features I have not used, thus cannot comment. 

*Story
The story is absent. While true you will have an opening cinematic, and a few in-game cutscenes the story is simple. Fight your way to the evil wizard and slay him. Avoiding spoilers, I will state that the boss fight and ending cinematic is just criminal. 10 hours of on an off gameplay to fight a boss with a few gimmicks and a story that gips you of any sense of accomplishment. Do you accomplish the primary goal? Technically yes, and it could've been a hell of a lot better.

*Final issues.
There are bugs in the game, and some abilities that you may rely heavily on for victory may just end up useless late-game. The trouble is, was it an intentional design decision by the developer or a lack of oversight during testing? The game as it stands has been out for a year, so I allow you to form that opinion. In short, I find many design decisions questionable of the developer, which hopefully by the time of Dark Quest 3 they will perfect their formula.

Is this game worth it? If you enjoy average dungeon-crawling in the style of hero-quest, for the price of a McChicken you'll technically get more value.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983740996', 'num_games_owned': 746, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1569270054}
review:
What was supposed to be a night of celebration in the kings castle turned into a night of horror. The sorcerer and his minions had returned and attacked when nobody expected. Within a few hours every man, woman and child was butchered, including the king. 

It is up to you to enter the castle to face madness and death on your ultimate quest to defeat evil.

Dark Quest 2 is a role-playing, turn-based dungeon crawler. The game starts as a very simple, primitive brawler, but gains tactical depth, the longer you play. That's because your characters change strongly throughout the course of the game and every new dungeon you enter is more demanding.

Dark Quest 2 lets you play with six different heroes. The barbarian, the dwarf, the dark monk, the wizard, the paladin and the archer. Each of these characters comes with very different characteristics, resulting in a very different game play experience, depending on the heroes you pick for your party.

While you start the game with a single hero, the barbarian, you can later play dungeons with up to four party members. During the game you can collect gold and potions. Gold can be used to craft better weapons, armor and magic items. Potions can be used to improve your heroes abilities. Additionally you can find special items in the dungeons that give you further advantages.

Each of the heroes comes with a very different set of abilities. The paladin has great healing and protection powers, while the barbarian shows advantages due to his physical strength. The wizard and the monk are physically weak but offer powerful magic. As expected the archer can carry out great long range attacks and the dwarf is a strong melee fighter and displays craftsmanship with traps.

Depending on the heroes you choose for your party and the talents you upgrade, you can influence the way you play. Defensive, aggressive or even stealthy.

In the late game you will counter an overwhelming number of enemies that you can only defeat with the right use of your abilities and tactics.

The game is very well balanced on normal difficulty and also very enjoyable. You will die a couple of times but you can re-play already finished dungeons to collect more gold and potions to upgrade your abilities and craft better equipment. That's the way it's meant to be played.

However, since the game comes with Steam workshop support there are ways to cheat. Some workshop maps allow you to easily collect gold and potions on specially designed maps. I do not recommend using these before finishing the game at least once. But of course this kind of help is helpful in hardcore difficulty mode.

Dark Quest 2 is a rather simple but very enjoyable old school game. If you have a nag for these kind of games I can strongly recommend Dark Quest 2.

Pros:
- it's fun
- simple but nice comic graphics
- very diversified heroes with very different abilities
- equip your heroes with special potions
- allows different tactics
- multiplayer mode
- Steam workshop support
- option to move very fast (helpful after first play-through)
- possibility to revive dead heroes in normal and easy difficulty (not in hardcore mode)
- you can visit a brothel before heading to the next dungeon to gain additional strength

Cons:
- I died a lot at the beginning
- after a while I found the music a little annoying  and turned it off

author: {'steamid': '76561198022121357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1640874649}
review: Se come me, dopo Heroquest, non avevate pi√π trovato un gioco che gli somigliasse, a parte le sue trasposizioni su amiga e pc di tanti anni fa, adesso non dovete attendere pi√π, ecco, lo avete trovato. Dark Quest 2 riprende in mano delle meccaniche molto simili ai dadi, dandoti l'impressione di lanciarli come in un gioco da tavolo, ma in realt√† autocalcola tutti i risultati, senza mostrarteli: il risultato √® un gioco fluido, che scorre molto bene, e che vi catapulter√† negli anni '90 con tante aggiunte molto carine e soddisfacenti. Anche se √® chiaramente ispirato ad Heroquest, Dark Quest 2 migliora tanti aspetti, una grafica disegnata in modo artistico, ambienti immersivi, musiche molto d'atmosfera epica, molte abilit√† da sbloccare e (Cosa che apprezzo molto) particolarmente coerenti con i personaggi stessi. E' un gioco che finalmente ha messo fine alla mia ricerca di epicit√† e sensazioni dei vecchi giochi da tavolo di una volta.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980138550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1569022383}
review:
Macht auf jeden Fall Spa√ü, war am anfange etwas frustrierend weil die Gruppe sehr schwach ist und man schon ein paar mal stirbt^^. Nach 2, 3 quests l√§uft es dann auch schnell besser und zum Gl√ºck kann man verstorbene Helden wiederbeleben. Ein sch√∂nes Designe gibt es au√üerdem. Wer auf TableTop games steht, dem kann ich es nur empfehlen! 

Ein Kontra hab ich allerdings, aber ist nicht die Welt.
Nach Ende eines Kampfes gibt es keine Funktion um zb. die ganze Gruppe zum n√§chsten Raum zu bewegen oder eine group selection oder so. Jeder Held mu√ü dann einzeln zum Durchgang geschickt werden. 

Also 9/10

review:
Un gradevole gioco fantasy con combattimenti a turni, la trama non √® il massimo dell' originalit√†, in pratica si deve sconfiggere il cattivo mago di turno, ma il suo sviluppo, attraverso le varie missioni √® gradevolmente vario.
Le fasi di combattimento sono interessanti e le ho apprezzate, mentre certi meccanismi di gestione delle risorse dei personaggi nel villaggio mi sono parse un poco macchinose, pur senza essere frustranti. 
Nel complesso un bel gioco, che ho completato in modalit√† normale in 12 ore.
Da valutare la componente "collaborativa" (?!) con amici di Steam, inoltre data la mia scarsa abilit√†, non mi sono cimentato con la modalit√† Hardcore.
Non male.

review: I really enjoyed this game. It was short and sweet.  Maybe bigger maps would add to the experience.  There was only one challenge that used 4 characters but it was exactly what I was looking for.   Dark Quest 2 goes on a fairly exclusive list of games where if Dark Quest 3 were to ever creep out of the shadows... it would be mine. A little tweek and....... awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074167152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1564965812}
review:
Could be a decent mobile game, completely fails as a PC game. It is like bare bones version of Hero's of Might & Magic meets Darkest Dungeon for 7-10 year olds. 

Cons:
1) Low content and none of the mechanics are fleshed out. (About 20 Items, 5 Traps, 20-30 Spells, 8-12 Enemy Types, etc...)
2) Most of the mechanics are heavy on RNG. 
3) Don't know why there are secret doors, its so obvious to find them. 
4) Moving characters around the room after fighting is a chore. 
5) Literally the only treasure you find in most maps is gold (20-30 gold that to). 
6) Blacksmith can craft 20 items most of which class specific - so 3 items per hero the entire game (2 Equip Slots Joke). 
7) Random quests, repetitive levels, no sense of progression. After 3 levels (1 hr) you have seen everything the game has to offer.
8) Hero resurrection is joke. You entire party can be revived with items for a pittance.
9) Useless NPCs, Merchant - sell some random things for gold (That is it, he does nothing else), Brothel - get a random bonus for 150 gold...
10) No town upgrades - No boss fights except the final boss...

Pros:
1) Music is decent but only 3-4 tracks on repeat.
2) Passable graphics and controls.
3) Tutorials were to the point and clear

Don't but this game as it is, it needs tons of content and updates.

Verdict: 3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198273375169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1562654852}
review:
I know I didn't play enough of the game for most of you to count it, but I enjoyed the short time I got to spend with it.

The combat is really simplified, down to single digits, and they expand upon the gameplay by allowing you to improve your characters. Personally the draw for me is the charm, it has these little animations for all sorts of things that make the game more enjoyable and shows the love the creators poured into making it.

One complaint I saw is that the game is apparantely too difficult, as repeating the same quest multiple times makes it gradually get more difficult. This to me seems like a silly problem, as I played this on hardest difficulty and have yet to lose a single troop, but maybe I'm just a super genius. I am willing to concede that.

Thats really all there is to it without spoiling every game mechanic for you to explore, its fun, its flashy, I like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198282341624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1563131843}
review:
Nettes Game f√ºr zwischendurch. Da es nicht besonders teuer ist, will ich meine Kritikpunkte als Verbesserungsvorschl√§ge verstanden wissen:

- eine minimale Sprachausgabe f√ºr die Helden w√§re sch√∂n. Es fehlt ihnen an Pers√∂nlichkeit
- Im Kampf sind die Figuren nicht "transparent", d. h. dass sie einzelne Quadrate so blockieren, dass sie mit der Maus nicht angeklickt werden k√∂nnen. Somit k√∂nnen die Helden nicht immer so bewegt werden, wie man m√∂chte und Fallen k√∂nnen nicht da platziert werden, wo man sie haben will.
- Es w√§re sch√∂n, wenn im Kampf die Wegpunkte f√ºr den letzten Schritt des Helden (nachdem dann eine Aktion nicht mehr m√∂glich ist) farblich in rot gekennzeichnet w√§re, damit man weiss "Alles klar, wenn ich dahin gehe, kann ich in diesem Zug nicht mehr k√§mpfen"
- Ich habe es im ersten Versuch auf "Normal" durchgespielt. Der Wiederholungswert ist eher gering, da keinerlei Erfolge o. √§. implementiert sind
- Es gibt nur eine einzige Quest f√ºr vier Helden, ansonsten sind es immer h√∂chstens drei. Da die Helden eher unausgewogen sind, bedeutet das, dass man immer mit denselben spielt. Der Zwerg ist besser als der Barbar, aber wenn ich den Zwerg habe, dann doppeln sich die F√§higkeiten teilweise mit dem Bogensch√ºtzen; der M√∂nch ist so stark, dass er unverzichtbar ist und der Magier ist besser als der Ritter. Also bestand meine Party immer aus: Zwerg, M√∂nch, Magier. Das ist einfach schade. Gut w√§re, wenn es etwas mehr Infos √ºber die jeweilige Quest g√§be. Mehr Fallen, mehr Monster, mehr Magie o. √§. Dann w√ºrde man mehr variieren, glaube ich.
- die Musik taugt nicht viel, ich habe sie im Spiel aufs Minimum runtergezogen
- es gibt nur wenig Gegenst√§nde beim Schmied, die Wahl f√ºr den jeweils besten Gegenstand f√ºr den einzelnen Helden f√§llt sehr leicht und schon nach zwei Dritteln des Spiels hatte ich alles, was ich wollte
- Die "Wahnsinns-Fallen" sind eine nette Idee. Das Problem: Lasse ich nur einen Charakter im Raum und l√∂se mit ihm die Falle aus, dann passiert mir gar nichts.
- Es w√§re gut, wenn es einen "Quest beenden"-Button g√§be. Ich musste 2-3 Mal Sch√§tze liegen lassen, weil die Quest automatisch beendet wurde bzw. weil eine "Secret-Passage" nicht als "Exit Dungeon" gekennzeichnet war
- Es gibt zwar 6-7 verschiedene Tr√§nke, aber ich habe nur 3 davon benutzt. Auch hier sind die Unterschiede zu gro√ü und es ist relativ fr√ºh klar, was man unbedingt braucht und worauf man verzichten kann

Also, wie gesagt, ein nettes Game und teilweise durchaus herausfordernd, aber auf jeden Fall verbesserungsf√§hig.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970545932', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1562846750}
review:
Great little game, as an old fart who bought hero quest as a boardgame and then the original computer game, this has some strong influences. I enjoyed playing and would love to see the developer do another sequel or even attempt Space Crusade, an old 40k version of a similar boardgame.

Little annoyances : Clicking behind characters to move or loot can be troublesome in isometric.

In the village if you scroll left, there is a vendor to sell stuff and a brothel for buffs. Really should know that visually on the screen.

When moving across a room with no enemies, some kind of party follow mechanic would speed it up. Instead of manually moving each character.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036380683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1559503835}
review:
Man beginnt mit einem Helden und ist am Ende mit bis zu 5 Helden unterwegs, von denen man aber meist nicht mehr als 3 mitnehmen kann. Jeder Held hat eine andere Klasse. Man k√§mpft abwechselnd im Schloss und r√ºstet sich dann im Dorf aus. Im Schloss findet man Tr√§nke mit denen man F√§higkeiten bei den einzelnen Helden freischalten kann. F√ºr das gefundene Gold kann man ein paar Ausr√ºstungsgegenst√§nde oder konsumierbare Flaschen kaufen.

So in etwa 10 Stunden ist man mit dem Spiel durch und hat den b√∂sen Zauberer hoffentlich besiegt. Ich habe dann den Schwierigkeitsgrad erh√∂ht und noch einmal angefangen. Irgendwie kam es mir dann nicht wirklich schwieriger vor. Als mir dann ein Held gestorben ist wollte ich ihn im Dorf wiedererwecken und siehe da das ging bei dem Schwierigkeitsgrad nicht. Na ja vorher lesen h√§tte nicht geschadet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003780341', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 868, 'last_played': 1636742853}
review:
Disclaimer: This review is from a co-op perspective only.

Dark Quest 2 is turn based game and actually a tribute to the 1989 Games Workshop boardgame title Hero's Quest, and does a great job with beutiful, quirky hand drawn graphics echoing of the 80's pen & paper rpg's. The lack of more generic 3d content is refreshing in the way it is made, and even though the animation might look a bit stiff remembering it's miniature game forefather might help. Another con due to the artstyle is the lack of customization, but honestly is out of the scope of the game and would feel wrong.

Beneath this rather simplistic looking surface the gameplay is surprisingly tactical in a way that encourages planning who will go first and doing what each turn.

The game is bascially a 'world' map where every mission marked on it is a dungeon of some kind. This is turn consists of a number of rooms and corridors filled with enemies and loot. Apart from money your most sought after bounty will be blue flasks of experience, which will let you upgrade your characters between missions.

Between dungeons you end up in the Village where you can rest, learn skills, buy potions, craft items etc.

Since each player can only control one character, a smaller party might have to decide on which one they will play depending on the type of challenge ahead. Luckily each player can keep a full roster of characters to play with and upgrades is not restricted to the character that collected the experience.

There are six different classes once fully unlocked and each one got seven or eight special abilities or skills:
* Barbarian - Think Conan with a big ass sword, a bunch of offensive mechanics and decent hp.
* Dwarf - Once fleshed out a decent tank, capable of digging in and holding the front. Also capable of some crowd control.
* Archer - A ranger type character with access to special arrow attacks and useful stuff like a heal, setting and detecting traps etc.
* Wizard - Can cast illusions, firewalls, lightning and wizardy stuff like that and is capable of dealing a decent amount of damage.
* Knight - A must have for a bigger group and can hold on pretty well tanking.
* Dark Monk - A strange bird this one, with situational abilities that sometimes are incredibly powerful. Can swap places with enemies and friends, make enemies attack eachother, kill any enemy and leach its hp, massdamage everyone in a room etc. 

The abilities/skills mechanics takes a while to figure out but in a nutshell:
* Abilites can normally be used once per mission. Upgrades, charges and potions can increase this number.
* Skills are either passive or active but can be used every turn.

Over this layer you also have a system of hit points, magic shielding and 'Fate' that you also have to take in consideration.

This means that the meta game consists of trying to figure out how you can combine different skillsets with your team mates.
The way you approach a dungeon with a Barbarian - Ranger duo is different from the solution you find with a Dark Monk - Dwarf one etc.
And that is the best part of the game in my opinion. Every character got a different playing style. If the Dwarf controls the horde of regular orcs, the Monk will pinpoint and take out ranged threats, like pesky witches that slowly sting you hp using needles and a voodoo doll.
Testing out your theories and watching this play out is a satisfying feeling.

The game also includes a Editor making it possible to craft levels for the Workshop, and even though it is a bit clunky and undocumented adds extra value and longevity to the game.

For gamers that enjoy co-op games like Divinity or Card Hunter this is a no brainer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030644336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 3908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1564843246}
review:
This game does an awesome job scratching that old HeroQuest itch. Yes, it's kind of luck-based. Yes, the combat is simple. Yes, the art, writing, and interface are all kind of hokey. Doesn't matter. I love this game. And there are enough choices in the party creation and character development systems between missions that you feel like your decisions have an impact on the way each dungeon plays out, which is important. Most significantly, there are a lot of items and skills for each hero, so UNLIKE in HeroQuest, the number of things your characters can do in combat ratchets up pretty quickly from the first dungeon.

Finally, a bit of open disclosure: I did get this game for free. I have a small YouTube channel, so small developers occasionally offer me free games to try. I just want to note, though, that as the owner of a 0-year-old baby, the limiting reagent in my gaming life is time, not money, so I ignore the vast majority of the games that I'm offered. I jumped at this one and fell in love with it immediately; my whole-hearted recommendation of this game is based on that fact, not on the fact I got it for free. I really hope this developer does well and makes many more games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040421250', 'num_games_owned': 19550, 'num_reviews': 743, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1560172965}
review:
In this video I take a look at Dark Quest 2 a dungeon crawling RPG game.
This is a simple title but fun and addictive. It has a simple graphical interface and gameplay mechanics but still offers very good strategic game play with it's turn based combat system. Once each mission is over you regroup at the town where you can buy, upgrade, rest, or improve. It also offers multi player if desired. It has a really cheap price and is well worth taking a look at.

Watch the video to see what the game is like.....
https://youtu.be/ltwngv9hKGc
Check'n Games, providing you with as many Let's Play's as we can.
Thanks for watching. Please like comment and subscribe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071776011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1563915417}

author: {'steamid': '76561197992965976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1559303874}
review:
Overall, it's less than what I had expected. The game itself does not really have all that much content in it, whereas the gameplay can be mildly annoying with the walking simulator moments it gives you, objects behind sprites that you can't click properly and whatnot.

I would only recommend this game at a significant discount, around the price tag of 5 $/‚Ç¨.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018878631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 1367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1015, 'last_played': 1563393966}
review:
Moin Leute, 

Dark Quest 2 ist ideal f√ºr Leute, die zu zweit Coop spielen wollen. Alleine kann man die Kampagne oder selbst erstellte Workshop Karten auch spielen, dann w√§hlt man einfach mehrere Helden, die man nach und nach bekommt. Die Story ist simple. T√∂tet den Zauberer. Die Kamapgne spielt sich recht fl√ºssig, manche sp√§teren Karten k√∂nnen kniffelig sein, da muss man dann doch mal nachdenken wie man seine Lebenspunkte schont. Auf "Einfach" spielt es sich sehr angenehm, da wirds erst am Ende schwerer. Auf Normal sieht es schon anders aus. Da sollte man seinen Charakter schon beherrschen. Sonst gibts auf die M√ºtze und alles wird m√ºhselig. 

Pro:
1. Grafik - Sehr h√ºbscher Comicstyle
2. Sound - Musik, Kampfger√§usche, Todesanimationen; alles sehr passend
3. Skills - Die nach und nach freischaltbaren Skills machen Spa√ü und erlauben im Zusammenspiel mit anderen Charakteren tolle Kombis. 
4. Crafting - Simpel gemacht (Gold als einzige Ressource), aber nette Items, die sp√ºrbar wirken
5. Ansicht des Dorfes - Liebevolle Details vom Bordell bis zur Schmied(in). 
6. Levelgestaltung - Unterschiedliche Mobs - Von Einfach bis Knackig, von Haudrauf bis Zauberer
7. Es gibt Fallen :-) Je nach Charakter vermeidbar oder einfach √ºbel
8. Tolle Karte mit Wegweiser (mehr oder weniger ;-))
9. Coop ! Macht zu zweit noch mehr Spa√ü
10. Gutes Spiel f√ºr wenig Geld 

Contra:
1. Umst√§ndliches Coop Men√º (Ready oder nicht Ready ist bl√∂d gemacht, Quest kann nur der Host starten, Manchmal sind Karten verbuggt, wenn einer einen Raum verl√§sst und der andere nicht mitgehen kann. Grade, wenn man zur√ºckl√§uft passiert sowas manchmal. 
2. Kein Autoloot nach Kampf ( Wenigstens vom Gold was offen rumliegt w√§re das eine sch√∂ne Option, wenn man das im Optionsmen√º ausw√§hlen k√∂nnte)
3. Aktiver Spieler ist nicht deutlich genug sichtbar. (Gr√ºne Umrandung schwer zu sehen)
4. Friedhof 20 %! des aktuellen Goldes ist zuviel! Meist muss man irgendwelche Tr√§nke kaufen, um sich wiederzubeleben und dann wieder verkaufen, um f√ºr was anderes Gold auszugeben, wie das Bordell, Taverne oder Drinks f√ºr den wiederbelebten Charakter zu kaufen. Bl√∂d gemacht!
5. Wegfindung manchmal doof! Wenn ein Charakter eine Falle ausgemacht hat umgeht der Charakter die nicht, sondern latscht gerne auch mal rein. (Kann nat√ºrlich auch vom Entwickler auf Old School gemacht sein)
6. Goldmenge erh√∂ht sich kaum bei steigendem Schwierigkeitsgrad oder im Verlauf der Kampagne. So muss man meist einfache Karten nochmal spielen, um sich wieder was kaufen zu k√∂nnen. Bissle unbalanced. Grade f√ºr Neulinge doof. 
7. Es k√∂nnten noch mehr Items sein und es w√§re sch√∂n, wenn das Itemmen√º pro Charakter sichtbar w√§re und nicht im Hintergrund noch die Symbole der anderen Items angegraut sind. Ist nicht so schick. 
8. Items manchmal buggy. Schwert +1 und dann trotzdem nur 1 Schaden, obwohl Normalangriff schon 1 Schaden macht. 
9. Kein Deutsch! Braucht man nicht unbedingt, aber w√§re trotzdem sch√∂n. 
10. Fehlender dritter Teil !!! Ich brauch neues Futter!!! 

Alles in allem macht das Spiel (grade im Coop) viel Spa√ü, ist g√ºnstig, sch√∂ne Grafik, einfache Steuerung, tolle Skills, nette und teilweise doofe Gegner, lustige Ger√§usche und es spielt sich sehr kurzweilig. Und l√§uft auf alten Rechnern und Laptops. Mehr davon und weiter so, liebe Entwickler !

author: {'steamid': '76561198062772350', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1558973091}

author: {'steamid': '76561197974088172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1558438811}
review:
Overall: fairly simple, plenty of fun choices and cool moments when your tactical use of skills pays off.

In Dark Quest 2 you take a party of heroes through a series of dungeons, each made up of a series of rooms, and slaughter lots of nasty monsters in turn-based combat.  There are a nice variety of encounters, twice as many heroes available as you can generally take into a dungeon so you can choose your party composition, and a bunch of items and potions to customise your heroes for different strategies.  Each hero also has a selection of useful skills learned using a shared resource for additional choice.  Shoutout to my Barbarian who failed his 80% courage test every single time.  There were a few minor annoyances/bugs, but nothing serious enough (on Normal difficulty anyway) to stop me recommending the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134086602', 'num_games_owned': 995, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1623368512}
review:
Primer Vistazo de Dark Quest 2: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zhX7WUZe-PQ

Mi primer juego de miniaturas fue el glorioso Warhammer Quest de la empresa Games Workshop. Todav√≠a lo tengo y cada tanto me hago una partidita, porque sigue siendo a mi gusto uno de los mejores boardgames del tipo dungeoncrawler que existen (si, a pesar de estar por momentos super desbalanceado y azaroso, eso no significa que no sea divertido)
Cuando me enter√© de la existencia del Dark Quest 2 autom√°ticamente pude ver las similitudes entre los juegos, y al probarlo me dej√≥ un buen sabor de boca, ya que si bien no puedo decir que sea lo mismo, me hizo acordar a aquellas partidas, con el viaje a la ciudad inclu√≠do. 
A mi gusto, muy recomendable si te gustan los rpgs con batallas t√°cticas por turno.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028612224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1537, 'last_played': 1555300793}
review:
Fun, light, casual game.

Leveling up without xp is very weird, specially cause you can explore the mechanics and level up all your heros to the max if you have enough patient to grab a flask and go back to town (repeat 200x).

Dungeons also can bug A LOT and leave your heroes stuck, making you lose your progress, frustrating.

Despite these two flaws, it's a really fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050016554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1555168594}
review:
Bof, je vais mettre un avis positif par d√©faut parce que je ne vois pas de gros d√©faut √† ce jeu mais je crois que je vais le laisser de c√¥t√©. Je ne sais pas trop pourquoi, je n'ai pas vraiment envie d'y jouer. 

Il n'y a pas la touche graphique et le ruissellement de stress d'un Darkest Dungeon, il n'y a pas la foultitude d'√©quipement et de butin d'un Monster Den, il n'y a pas l'atmosph√®re de myst√®re qui pousse en avant d'un Tower of Time. Peut-√™tre que simplement j'ai trop de jeux du m√™me style pour rendre justice √† celui-ci, il me parait en quelque sorte banal.

Je joue solo, c'est peut-√™tre plus sympa avec des potes.

review: I never heard of the board game this was based on until I read the reviews, but it sounds like I really missed out on something back in the day. This version did lock up on me several times, but restarting the game helped with that problem. Even with those bugs, I found it to be very enjoyable and played thought it several times. An online friend bought this game for me, so he could play it in multiplayer mode and I hope I find something this good to send him in return. It's a lot better than you would expect for the $7.99 price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962266140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1554841806}
review:
Habe das Spiel mit 2 Spieler versucht durchzuspielen. Geht aber leider nicht wirklich, weil mann mit 2 Spielern nur 2 Charaktere steuern kann. Das ist bei einer 4 Spieler Map sehr *********

Eine M√∂glichkeit Random-Spieler mit zunehmen gibt es soweit ich weis nicht.

Manchmal ist es verbuggt, so das ich den Mitspieler rauswerfen musste und er dann den Puff-Buff verloren hat und neu kaufen musste.

Mann kann nur 2 verschiedene Items pro Charakter tragen.

Idee nett, Umsetzung k√∂nnte noch besser sein.

Das beste daran war das Puff in das mann sehr oft gehen musste.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139028494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1578313934}
review:
Decent okay little game

pros:
decent graphics
easy combat
old fachion boardgame feeling

cons:
6 characters to choice from but really only 3 of them are any good.
game is abit short, completed it in 1 nights run.
Melee characters are gimped due to game mechanics of enemies Defence that blocks close to 80% of the time.

overall i'm satisfied.
but if a Dark Quest 3 comes, I would expect the cons to be fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032447372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1554584996}

author: {'steamid': '76561198110569056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1553963089}
review:
I wanted to love this game. Huge fan of Hero Quest, still own the board game =D

For me the game breaker is the fact that when replaying a mission, the mission gets harder. More monsters/traps/ect.

How do you farm a previous mission to get stronger for the next, when the previous mission itself is vamped up so heavy?

Example, mission #3, first room, one bad encounter with 3 mage, 2 warriors, and an assassin mostly wiped the party outright, barbarian is left with 2 hp, so party throws up the white flag and hoofs it back to town. Not enough gold to revive and heal everyone. So we try and take the revived archer and the wounded barb on mission #2, That way we can earn some gold and revive the dwarf. And actually afford to sleep at the inn.

Mission #2 is now harder since we beat it once. Every room has more mobs and there are extra traps to trigger as well. The archer and barbarian do not make it. So one bad encounter basically ended the game. It was impossible to recover from an almost party wipe, even in the early game.

I don't understand the idea of making prior missions harder and harder every time it's played. How is someone supposed to recover from a bad adventure? I didn't like this aspect of the game at all and feel it ruins it.

Also as noted on other posts, why doesn't the hero that notices a trap on the floor, STOP? Would any adventurer you know keep walking over a trap they noticed before stepping on it?

Multiplayer is limited to one character each, any reasons? Why can't we control up to two each for a full party?

This could be a nice little game, but it needs work.
developer_response:
You can replay 1 or 2 times the same mission before it becomes too hard. Some missions should be avoided playing too many times as it can be very hard. There is no good reason to replay a mission that many times unless you are going farm blue pots which is why this mechanic was implemented in the first place....

You should venture forth and try new missions or try and reach the bonus dungeons which will give you significant boost in power. There are multiple ways of going forward but as you found out.... playing the same dungeon 10 times is not the way forward....

Traps, you can upgrade detect traps to level 3 on dwarf or archer so they can stop falling to traps.... they will test their perception when stepping to a trap.

Multiplayer, we decided it would be easier if each player just controls their hero. Maybe it was not the best idea... however the game is still beatable with 2 heroes only if you have the right heroes... but it‚Äôs a bit of a challenge...

If you find the game too challenging, then consider restarting with a better hero setup (some abilities are more useful than others)

author: {'steamid': '76561197989737094', 'num_games_owned': 1045, 'num_reviews': 212, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1553458620}
review:
Game is okay, I guess. First levels are more fun, last few levels where you have to gather parts of amulet are really tough, and generally it is expected that there is only one correct party setup. Which brings to issue, that you would have to grind previous levels multiple times to level multiple classes and try try try until you found the right setup.

6/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049813652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 3196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2191, 'last_played': 1619223912}
review: You like old dungeon games? Then you can not miss this one out. Nicely executed, carefully drawn old style Dungeon Crawler. Typical story, nice enemies, crystal clear rules and fitting abilities. Few characters to choose from, each is balanced and good. Nice playground for all the skills and possibilities. You will find just the right amount of everything here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062206253', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1550597205}
review:
[b]Sehr cool gemacht allerdings auch mit kleinen Bugs[/b]

Rundenbasiert durch die Dungeons und vorsichtig die Gegner niedermetzeln. 

Optisch hat es etwas von Hero Quest und leider genauso zuf√§llig laufen teilweise die K√§mpfe ab. Ist der Held noch nicht so hoch geskilled haut man mit dem Schwert der Axt doch sehr gerne mal ins Leere und die Gegner treffen gut. Etwas grinden muss dann von Zeit zu Zeit doch sein, oder man nimmt sich eine Custom Map mit der das schneller geht. 

Leider sind, wenn man auf Bugs trifft diese spielzerst√∂rend. Einmal musst ich aus dem Level fl√ºchten, da es f√ºr den Barbaren angeblich keine M√∂glichkeit mehr gab weiter zu laufen. Im Level vor dem Zauberer kann in der Anfangsformation der Helden ein falscher Schritt bedeuten, dass die Figur den Level verl√§sst. Dann ist es im Prinzip nicht mehr zu schaffen. 

F√ºr mich eine Kaufempfehlung, ggf. auf einen Sale warten. 

+ Einfach zu erlernen
+ Skills sind ziemlich interessant
+ Musik nervt zu keinem Zeitpunkt

+/- Animationen der Helden beim Laufen (gerade vom Barbaren) etwas sonderbar
+/- Unbeskilled muss man sich anfangs durchbei√üen 

- Minimale Bugs, die jedoch Gamebreaker sind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107774137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14741, 'last_played': 1690645517}

Le workshop est bien garni, ce qui permet de faire de nouvelles aventures cr√©es par les autres joueurs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986030006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1548028755}
review:
Rating for Single Player Thumbs Up! Rating for Co-op Thumbs Down. 

Concept and gameplay loops are good and co-op is fun until you reach the last 5 or six missions. Granted I am playing on Normal with a friend, but artifacts do not work in co-op. Also most misisons allow three characters but for some reason in co-op you can only use two. In one map we managed to kill 8-10 werewolves with only two of us just to die to the next room. Artifacts need to be allowed for co-op or at least the full player amount. Unfortunately at this point if we want to beat the game it will have to be single player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040122432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1547840911}
review:
It is quite good game. Simple and linear. It is not the best one, I do not how many devs worked on it, but it is most of the time decent. Music is nothing special, graphics are enough good to play. Animations are almost zero, but it do not destroy game. 

There are few little annoying things:
1. You can not move your party togheter. You need to move everybody one by one. I have 3 characters for now, later I probably will have more. In addition that there are a lot of empty areas, you need to move them one by one - it takes time and is waste of gameplay.
2. You can not use wasd keys... camera only move with arrow keys. I discovered it like after few frustraction moments, when camera behaved strange.
3. Sometimes there is problem to pick items - especialy when you party member is in front of it. Sometimes there is also problem with moving to the next room - the same reason.

In overall, there are a lot of better choices than this. Still, if you love turn based games, you like linear story, you like that there is no countless items (in this game every item is exactly one and unique), you do not bother with little flash-like graphics, you do not need great music, and you like to finish game in finite time - guess it is position good consider.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007286350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1625042103}
review:
Picked this up on sale for less than 5 euro. It was a positive surprise. Easy to learn, easy to play but challenging on normal. I like the maps, graphics and music and a very large and attractive userinterface.

What I lack is more items to buy. The equipment is very limited and static right now. So if you find a level too hard you can only replay it and hope for better random results in a combat. While there are some tactics involved in how you use your characters and in which order and also placement I would like to see initiative, flanking etc in a sequel. But other than that, well worth the money.

Par contre, j'ai remarqu√© qu'√† partir du 5 ou 6eme essai les donjons deviennent tr√®s/trop difficile, nos chances de toucher avoissent les 10%, alors que les monstres n'ont aucune difficult√© √† nous toucher.

J'esp√®re que les artefacts √† gagner permettent de palier √† ce soucis, car me faire d√©foncer 2 persos par un seul mob totalement intoucheable dans un donjon niveau 6 √ßa fait un peu mal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015768220', 'num_games_owned': 346, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1546123829}
review:
Interesting game with a lot of potential that is held back by bad design choices and game-breaking bugs (or unexplained features).

[u][b]Negative[/b][/u]

It was pretty disappointing to find out that playing it in 2 player co-op results in each player controlling only a single hero, and not 2 heroes each. It comes down to combining the 2 heroes to create some borderline cheese strategy to beat some of the levels later in the game. It also makes blue pots for skill points almost useless as soon as you level up your main hero to max as you can only use 1 hero in a level (it's only worth collecting them to level up a different hero in case your 2 hero setup doesn't work against particular level's creatures or if you really want to play a different one every level to not be bored). Similar thing happens with items as you can easily purchase the items for that hero in the first few levels and after that the gold isn't really used for anything other than refilling potions and buffing up before each level. Levels have max player count in their description, but it's perfectly fine to start a 1 player mission in 2 player co-op. 

Some mechanics really don't make sense, such as an archer being able to spot the floor traps, but still having to step onto them because it's the only path into the next room. Combined with pathfinding, it would be normal to either go around the trap once it's detected, or at least stop the turn for the player to select a new destination (to recalculate pathfinding). The result, however, is your archer just stepping into the trap even though it got discovered, because you have no way of stopping the movement. There were also instances where pathfinding preferred to go over the curse event tiles rather than over the free path that got cleared by the partner's hero clearing one of the curse event tiles. Since camera angle is fixed, it is really hard to aim at a specific tile behind a unit (especially behind big units), which makes some moves almost impossible (and during the "cutscenes" the black bars sometimes even hide pieces of dialogs).

Then there are description errors. The archer heal description says it heals for 3/4/5, but it heals for 2/3/4. Unique artifacts say they give +1 fate, +1 magic armor, but neither is given. Some things could use some additional description to know how they work, for example Monk's flame circle deals 2 dmg lvl 2, and on lvl 3 it casts a circle from each friendly hero, but that circle only deals 1 dmg now.

Finally, there are bugs like converting a unit with a Monk and going with it first into the next room, which makes your heroes unable to enter that room and not able to choose a different room as everyone has to go into the same room. From what I've seen on the Steam forum, the said bug has been known for a while (although it may have been fixed and then reappeared, but it should still be fixed as it soft-locks the level). During co-op desync happens randomly without any warnings and non-host player is soft-locked.

[u][b]Positive[/b][/u]

The levels are short to medium length with limited equipment and ability usage which makes strategising important. Abilities are quite different between characters , but still simple to learn and get used to if you want to switch characters often.

The visuals are nice, enemy units especially look great.

Co-op is well made with players being able to give each other order of turn execution to allow deeper strategies between the players.

Custom maps to provide some sort of extra content (haven't tried them personally).

author: {'steamid': '76561198067727061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1550328298}
review: Classic turn based RPG. Unlockable and upgradable party, with lots of weapons to craft and skills to choose and master. Hours and hours of addictive fun for any fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093696053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1553970750}
review:
It's rather straight and simple for what it is. If i could recommend a slight change needed then it would be during the dungeon crawl/walk through you have to do each character individually for movement through each room which can get quite tedious. The game play is not very complex. You can also farm the items needed to upgrade skills so it can either be challenging or easy depending on how you want to go about it.

I would not recommend this for the full price though. It is a good game for when you just want something simple to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128840035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1545504782}
review:
I thought it was a fun game, I got it on sale and it was more than worth the price.  

It has a straightforward system that's easy to jump in to.   Lots of small quests which are all interesting and don't drag on or get repetitive.   No grinding is required in this game.

The amount of content is limited but enough to have given me 18 hours to finish it for the first time, I tried a couple of parties along the way.   There is not a giant learning curve but enough to reward good strategy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999263046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 860, 'last_played': 1636190117}
review:
SYNOPSIS:
As others will likely write, this is a modern homage to Hero Quest. But if you didn't grow up or are unaware of Hero Quest, it won't matter; it's merely a quick way to describe this game in one sentence.

This is a turn-based isometric dungeon crawler but each dungeon is "misson-based" - meaning that this is not an epic 'top-to-bottom' romp like a roguelike, but broken down into smaller dungeons, each with a specific task/designs in mind.

You start with the Barbarian, who is as you would assume - melee and damage; but the more missions you complete, you can add more people to your backend team - I say that because you can collect up to 6 adventurers but most of the time can only take in 2-3 within a mission; never 5 or 6 and only one instance there is 4 allowed.

Buy potions, weapons/armour, spells/abilities (dependant on adventurer), visit a brothel for an extra edge into the next mission and heal party embers when necessary.

Gameplay consists of "Move and Action"; you can Move a certain amount of tiles and you can Attack once (by default) with each adventurer. Same rules apply for the enemies.

And that's it, in a nutshell - this is a simple game but has a lot a enojoyment for the time to you do spend on it.


SUMMARY:
For me, I really enojyed this game and I hope the Devs add more content (more missions, adventurers, equip, GFX, etc) in the future - note: there is an editor included with the game - I haven't tinkered with this yet and unfortunately there is yet (as of this review) to be any custom dungeons made.

I think for some people, this will not be enough content and depth to immerse into - it's not a "roguelite" but more akin to being a "boardgame with life" if that makes sense. For my tastes, I love the GFX, the Isometric look and feel (the music in this is Awesome, by the way - sounds similar to the Amiga Hero Quest game ). It is a massive improvement upon the first Dark Quest, 

I'd recommend getting this on Sale as it stands only because (I believe) it needs more Dev Content - having an editor is great, but at end of it, we are limited by what content is provided to us. I can't make a swamp level if the tiles don't exist, etc..

author: {'steamid': '76561198015889996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 818, 'last_played': 1543791699}
review:
Very fun game. Brings back memories from Hero Quest. Gameplay is easy to learn and hard to master, with tactics becoming very important late game.

Pros: nice graphics, custom maps, diversity of heroes, good RPG feel.

Cons: Clicking on tiles is somewhat difficult on some battles, repetitive music, little variety of itens.

If this game had deeper RPG aspects like hero levels, more equipment slots, more named dungeons with procedurally generated maps (and bosses that droped loot) and equipment diversity it would be perfect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055725979', 'num_games_owned': 1326, 'num_reviews': 262, 'playtime_forever': 1312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1312, 'last_played': 1541200781}
review:
Combates t√°cticos bajo algunas directrices estrat√©gicas, trabajando bajo un sistema de numeraci√≥n reducida y probabilidad estable. Esto resume formalmente y repetitivo lo que haremos durante todo el juego.
Los combates se inician al entrar en una sala con monstruos. Se juegan por turnos, enteros para cada jugador y hasta su finalizaci√≥n o huida. Se desarrollan en un plano cuadriculado e isom√©trico que sirve de base para la t√°ctica. 
En el turno podremos hacer hasta cuatro cosas con cada personaje en el orden que queramos: mover, atacar, usar habilidades y usar pociones, con la regla de que ejecutar el ataque b√°sico gastar√° todos los puntos de movimiento. Las habilidades y uso de pociones no gastan acciones, aunque tienen que ser usados con sabidur√≠a porque se gastan. Los puntos acci√≥n unicamente se asignan al movimiento, delimitado para cada uno de nuestros personajes y monstruos.

Presenta poca complejidad en la jugabilidad pero se realza por el margen de maniobra que se logra en la cuadr√≠cula. As√≠ mismo, la evoluci√≥n y personalizaci√≥n del grupo lo nutren de forma considerable para formar una t√°ctica s√≥lida.
Tiene un desarrollo jugable de erosi√≥n en el que los fallos y errores no se castigan, m√°s bien se basa en un compendio general a largo plazo que puede resultar asfixiante si no jugamos bien. El fuerte del juego radica en jugar con las habilidades y con todos los personajes durante el turno, racionando y estabilizando, con la idea de subsanar los fallos y mantener una integridad hasta el final de cada misi√≥n. Para lograr un desaf√≠o primordial que conjugue con su jugabilidad no podremos hacer uso de recargar la partida si algun suceso no nos ha gustado.

La estructura del juego va por misiones y preparaci√≥n en un pueblo: tenemos que aguantar hasta finalizar la misi√≥n para volver a recuperarnos. Cada misi√≥n finalizada nos proporcionar√° oro y nuevos puntos de habilidad en relacci√≥n a lo que hemos conseguido, con la raz√≥n de evolucionar los personajes, comprar objetos y demandar alg√∫n que otro servicio renovador.
Las misiones son mazmorras. La morfolog√≠a de cada una va por salas de distinto tama√±o con uno o m√°s enlaces en sus lados para interconectarlas, formando un conjunto de salas de diferente √≠ndole que atribuye una secundaria jugabilidad de ir descubriendo y navegando por la mazmorra. Las trampas y tesoros, junto a las salas ocupadas por enemigos, cubrir√°n y sustentar√°n la base de combates de estrategia t√°ctica. El juego se convertir√° en medianamente firme.

Comenzaremos jugando con el heroe de clase Barbaro y al finalizar la primera misi√≥n, ya en el pueblo, reclutaremos a otro de los disponibles. En total son 6: Barbaro, Arquero, Enano, Caballero, Monje Oscuro y Mago. Para acceder a los siguientes tendremos que ir completando m√°s misiones, aunque solo podremos llevar un n√∫mero m√°ximo para cada misi√≥n, tres por regla general. Cada heroe y monstruo cuenta con su ficha de personaje y habilidades. La ficha sirve de referencia para comprender todo su sistema de juego de forma gradual. Es una ficha ligera y simp√°tica.

Tiene su firmeza e incluso un atractivo visual de fantas√≠a pero est√° demasiado encauzado a un √∫nico fin que siembra una pena y gloria. El apartado t√©cnico en dibujo y animaciones resulta bastante limitado y gen√©rico. El componente literal, interpretativo u observatorio apenas existe. El protagonismo y libertad del jugador y las posibilidades de juego general est√°n demasiado dirigidas hacia su pilar; carece de objetivos y aspectos secundarios. Bajo estos menesteres decae bastante porque no resulta arraigado, no tiene fundamento representativo y argumentativo.

Nota: 3,3
1,2 combates t√°cticos por turnos
0,8 decisi√≥n recaida al jugador 100%
0,8 sistema de reglas, probabilidad estable
0,3 ficha de los personajes y monstruos
0,2 atractivo visual isom√©trico

√çndice de recomendaci√≥n: 60%

author: {'steamid': '76561198030785140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1708, 'last_played': 1539901852}
review:
Dark Quest 2 is a dungeon exploring game with very simple mechanics. Almost everything can be done with a click of the left mouse button. However, it‚Äôs not an easy game. 

You start the game as a Barbarian, but are later able to change or add additional heroes to your party. There are a total of 28 quests. Each quest has its own maze of a map to explore, complete with gold, gems, magic pots, traps, and monsters. The gold and gems are used to buy potions, craft items, obtain temporary bonus stats, heal heroes, and resurrect them if they have fallen. Everything is expensive, and money can be quite scarce. The magic pots are used to upgrade abilities and skills. These are also relatively scarce. Traps can only be detected by a skill or by the use of a crafted item, and some traps are unavoidable. 

Each hero can only have up to 2 crafted items and at most 2 potions. Once equipped and set out on a quest, your heroes cannot trade items or potions amongst themselves. Very early on in the game you‚Äôll enter rooms with enemies vastly outnumbering your party. To succeed you have to use the limited abilities and skills of your heroes and pray for some luck. Also, since, all abilities can only be used once per quest, you have to be prudent in their use, and again lucky. If you use a powerful ability to kill a weak goblin in one room and then enter the next room to face a strong werewolf, you‚Äôre in trouble. However, if things start to go really bad, you can quit the quest, keep all discovered pots, half of the discovered gold, and head back to town to heal (assuming you have enough cash).

I liked a lot of things in Dark Quest 2:
‚Ä¢	The setting with a group of heroes off to fight an evil sorcerer locked in a castle was great.
‚Ä¢	The characters and maps are all beautifully drawn.
‚Ä¢	The music is very good, though it does quickly get repetitious.
‚Ä¢	 The various quests, with different maps, loot, and enemies were fine.

Some things I didn‚Äôt like so much:
‚Ä¢	Combat is turn-based and hero placement is important, but the camera is fixed. A couple of times I was unable to place my hero on the desired spot. A camera rotate function would have been helpful. 
‚Ä¢	I assumed that my party would continually grow, but only 1 quest allowed more than 3 heroes.
‚Ä¢	A number of abilities are weak, or next to worthless.
‚Ä¢	A few quests I had to quit because a character got stuck and I could not continue.

All in all, Dark Quest 2 was well worth its asking price. For me, the plusses far outweighed the minuses. If you‚Äôre looking for a beautifully drawn dungeon crawl, requiring you to carefully budget your hero‚Äôs money and abilities, Dark Quest 2 will give you 20+ hours of light-hearted fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970716750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1535272607}
review: Look, the game itself gameplay wise, is not terrible. Combat it the early stages is fairly easy but it has the potential to be quite difficult nearing the end of the game, requireing conservation of resources. Positioning, good use of skills, etc. The problem overall is how absolutely unwieldly the interface is. EVERYTHING is through the mouse. Every. Single. Thing. No hotkeys, no shortcuts, nothing. Want to see the map? Nope, don't push M, you go click on it. Want to close a window? Nope, don't hit Esc, you go click that X in the corner you slave you. Perhaps you'd prefer to move say, your Dwarf first each turn so you can check for traps? Well by god you'd better be ready for hovering madness and hoping you click that shorty each and every time because A) there's no way to make him the first default character (no dragging portaits to move turn positioning around here, no SIR!) and B) there's, you guessed it, no keybind to select a given character slot! For the icing on the cake, besides aaaaall the other clicks you have to do already, you'd better be ready to click your freaking FINGERS OFF so you can finish the game because JUST moving from room to room (and each map/quest has 10-15 minimum) you have to double click the exit of that room for every. single. character. ALL OF EM. Have a party of 4 and realize you need to backtrack 5 rooms so you can get all your skill potions? Well then partner be ready to click a minimum of 80 freaking times to do that simple wander about. A double click per toon, per room= "there and back again: a Dark Quest story". All this might be fine if it was a touch screen game but this is a freaking PC game folks. It goes beyond inane to not even have a rudimentary system of hotkeys or at a BARE MINIMUM the ability to move your entire party from room to room without clicking a bajillion times. There's a decent game here but it is positively buried underneath a UI that has no idea where it is or what its doing.
