author: {'steamid': '76561198014313110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 875, 'last_played': 1535037892}
review:
If you like turn based combat games, this game is quite allright to be bought in a sale.
It's fun, simple and pretty (not very original though)
A lot of people mentioned it has a feel of a very eased out Darkest Dungeon, and it really does

However, there are several things that are just wrong in this game:
- UI and usability are weird and bad, it's hard to click on the desired tile sometimes, usual key shortcuts aren't there and despite some tutorial screens, some things lacks explaining.
- Very short, very easy and forgiving... except for the character permadeath on hardcore mode, which is disproportional to everything else.
- Lot's of exploits, specially around upgrades and gold
- Almost no lore at all
- 4 members party only shows up at the very end of the game, very frustrating
- Multiplayer is completely useless

author: {'steamid': '76561197998568769', 'num_games_owned': 671, 'num_reviews': 828, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1534023240}
review:
8/10

I loved Dark Quest 2. I'm always interested in co-op turn based strategy, so I've had my eye on this one since Early Access. However, I waited on the full release before taking the plunge. For the co-op experience, both you and your partner control one character. I focused on the Dark Monk, the Holy Knight, and the Archer, and my co-op partner focused on the Dwarf, Barbarian, and Wizard. You have a town that serves as your "home base." While here, you can buy potions and items, spend blue vases (skill points) to acquire or upgrade skills, heal or resurrect your characters, sell treasures, or even visit the brothel for a temporary stat boost. When ready to depart, you'll be taken to an overworld map that looks something like the overworld in Super Mario Bros. 3. From here, it's clear where you need to get to, but there are multiple routes to do so.

Often, while playing, we'd run into a level that seemed insurmountable. However, we typically just chose a different direction to pursue on the overworld map, and we were then able to make progress. Later, we would often acquire new skills or think of a different way to use skills that we already had, and conquer the previous levels that had defeated us. We were eventually able to complete every level (on the normal difficulty, at least). Our favorite combination of characters was the Wizard and the Holy Knight. Here's a sample highlight: we ran into a difficult room with a good number of hard-hitting enemies, each with 3-4 health a piece. However, I saw that there was a 1-square wide bottleneck that the enemies would be forced to use in order to approach. I (the Holy Knight) activated my damage-absorbtion shield and stood right at the exit of the bottleneck. Although I took a hit or two, the enemies then lined up as expected in the bottleneck on their respective turns. The Wizard, anticipating this development, then cast a Tornado spell that travels in a straight line as far as possible, dealing 4 damage to every enemy it touches. Just like that, five goblins were defeated!

You'll often run into situations where creative thinking can get you out of a jam. Other spells that have great utility are the Wizard's "Fire Wall" spell and the Holy Knight's "Bless" ability. However, don't underestimate the power of the Dark Monk, who can simultaneously kill an enemy and steal its health with one of his spells.

Although I had a ton of fun with Dark Quest 2, there was no shortage of bugs to be found, and these hampered the experience a bit. First of all, the magic shields that you acquire for your characters seem to block the magical attacks of very few enemies. Especially towards the end of the game, I was repeatedly getting struck by lightning (if this isn't a magical attack, what is?) that penetrated my magical shields. This was especially irritating as the Holy Knight, who has a passive ability that can steal magical shields from enemies that are successfully damaged. In addition, the ability of the Wizard to turn an enemy to ice is also supposed to cause adjacent enemies to lose their turns - in practice, we did not witness this, with enemies around the frozen enemy still taking their turn as normal. My co-op partner also glitched into a set of stairs in one of the later levels, forcing a restart. Additionally, we often had to restart the game when my co-op partner was unable to see that I had launched a level and was waiting for him to join.

I also felt that the "fate" mechanic is not explained well (or at all). For new players, each instance of "fate" allows you to stay alive after taking lethal damage. Another oddity is the way that the player must move to pick up gold. After clearing a room of enemies, you can pick up all of the gold in the room in one turn, provided you only move to empty spaces surrounding the gold, rather than clicking on the gold itself. If you click on the gold, you'll move to that pile, pick up the gold, and your turn will end. In addition, as other reviewers have said, it can be difficult to target a space behind one of your other characters. However, I found that I could typically move here if I took a little bit of extra time to ensure that my mouse cursor was positioned in the small window that allowed me to do so. It could be that this issue is less important when playing with fewer characters in each map (as in co-op).

However, if you like co-op turn-based strategy and don't mind putting in a bit of extra thought in terms of approaching some of the situations on offer, I feel confident in saying you'll dig Dark Quest 2. Hopefully, the developer will patch the game to include some additional clarification for certain mechanics, to ensure that spells work as intended, and to improve general stability for online play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975735048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1233, 'last_played': 1660256919}
review:
Un jeu qui sent bon se bon veil H√©ro Quest tout en apportant sa patte graphique et son lot de nouveaut√©s. Si vous trouvez que ce jeu n'est pas si difficile, c'est uniquement parce que les modes "facile" et "normal" sont l'entrainement, le vrai jeu commence au hardcore avec le permadeath qui va bien.
Le point d√©licat c'est l'√©quilibrage entre les perso, car franchement je me vois mal comment me passer d'un Nain aussi pratique : d√©t√©ction et d√©samor√ßage des pi√®ges, peu replacer des pi√®ges d√©samorc√©s, bouclier imp√©n√©trable et qui renvoit les projectiles, peu placer des barils qui bloquent et bl√®ssent les monstres ... et le top c'est le buff du drop d'or.
Apr√©s les autres persos ont aussi leurs points forts, le Barbare qui fonce dans le tas en mode berzerk, le Moine Sombre qui tiens le role du n√©cromentien, la Paladin qui peut r√©ssusiter les compagnons morts et les soigner, le Mage qui fait des gros trous dans les rangs √©nemies et enfin la Scout qui fait un peu de tout et qui sert √† rien ... Il faut donc bien pr√©voir son coup √† la composition de chaque √©quipe.
Un bon point √©galement d'avoir la possibilit√© de cr√©er des maps et de les partager sur le workshop !

author: {'steamid': '76561198006260288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 294, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1587016317}
review:
Never had soo much fun in a dungeon.

I decided to give it a try despite the apparently damning Sinistrad review, as there seemed to be a stack of alternative views. I have no regrets - some people seem to like the sound of their own voice. I had no problems!

Have only played to date on the normal level. It seems (at this level) to give you a bit of latitude. There were the normal learning curve experiences, but, past that it has been great to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064989269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1651843751}
review:
Simple y llanamente: la mejor adaptaci√≥n de HeroQuest que encontrar√°s en el mercado.

Entre 6 y 8 horas de mazmorreo por turnos con los m√≠ticos arquetipos de h√©roe: B√°rbaro, Caballero, Brujo, Arquero, Enano y Monje. Miles de salas por explorar, trampas a evitar, orcos y goblins por doquier a los que derrotar...y un malvado hechicero que se oculta en lo m√°s profundo de su fortaleza. Una delicia ochentera, vamos.

Pros:
- Feeling HeroQuest por los cuatro costados
- Mazmorras en general muy bien dise√±adas y entretenidas
- El sistema de habilidades es simple, pero suficientemente amplio como para resultar divertido.
- Dise√±o de personajes, entorno y apartado audiovisual vistoso y agradable.
- Engancha de principio a fin.
- El precio: 7,99‚Ç¨ es una ganga, y si lo pillas en rebajas ya es un aut√©ntico chollo.

Contras:
- Alg√∫n bug aislado con el que lidiar (en la pen√∫ltima mazmorra uno de mis personajes desapareci√≥ del escenario, teniendo que reiniciar el nivel)
- Las animaciones de los personajes son bastante ortop√©dicas.
- Es un juego muy de nicho, para fans de los juegos de tablero, por lo que no gustar√° a quien busque un rpg o un juego estrat√©gico de mayor profundidad.

Recomendad√≠simo a los que esperaban un videojuego que hiciera justicia a Heroquest: este es vuestro juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080123570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 720, 'last_played': 1532860454}
review:
Finally finished DQ2...
Loved the music (even if a few more tracks of the same quality would have been nice) and art.
Nice numerical adaptation of the boardgame with simple mechanics but some different ways to crawl through the dungeon  environments.
Characters really have different roles and each one may shine if paired well, allowing a few different team setups.
The modding tools and Steamworkshop are well implemented as well.

My two cents for DQ3 or any following project:

1/Visibility:
Some squares can't be targeted due to characters blocking the path. Either use larger squares and smaller unit models or add a toggable transparency feature.

2/Pathing:
Some traps seem to be recognized by the AI, some not. I would settle for something like "everything you've spotted" is taken into account during AI pathing.

3/Counter intuitive:
The first character leaving a room should end up in the frontline in the next room and not in the back row.
Moving to the movement range limit ends turn while clicking on an enemy positioned outside your movement range makes your unit move and attack. Both "click" methods should yeld the same result imho.

4/Gear:
Would have loved more "game changer" objects, granting skills rather than "+ to x".

author: {'steamid': '76561197995161319', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1537544213}
review:
Some thoughts on Dark quest 2

Short: I really like the game; the base mechanics, theme/artstyle, graphics and drawings are really nice. The game is enjoyable and easy to pick up. Also the price is low.

I posted this reveiw also as a thread in the forum:

I just wanted to share some thougts about Dark Quest 2.

Things that I would like to see in the game or on a successor:

- A unclick/abort option(on heal/abilities)
- More voices/voiceover.
- Option to abort started action.
- More medieval themed music that fits the game.
- Tooltips/info when hoovering over stats.
- Status effect info.
- Farer view on map.
- Show marker for end dungeon when reavealed it.
- All the things Stormchaser mention in the post: "Wishlist for DQ 3"
from 18 Mar @ 11:34am:

- Names for characters.
- Deeper XP / level up / skill / magic / equipment system.
- More tactics (initiative, flanking, more active skill / spell uses etc).
- Dynamic visuals for armor and weapons.
- Random procedurally created dungeon crawling?

Other things:

- A litle too much animation on the breathing animation effect?
- Block turn potion, dosent work in the end of players turn?
- Bug when all party dead it costs money from brothel without any effects.
- Right click veiw is unresponsive.
- The game seems to use alot of CPU/GPU, why?
- Its possible to die to save money...
- Some exits do not show up as a exit.
- Stairs is a hassle.
- Stair stuck bug.
- Stuck outside map bug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039655160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1532061627}
review:
Great Combination of Rogue-like, rpg and strategy elements, the best thing for me is that i can play coop with my brother
we Finished it in 3 days in normal dificulty, but the real challenge seems to be chaos

More good things:
-Art is very dark feel which is so uique this days
-Lore and music
-Price

Bad things:
-Campaing is a lil too short

author: {'steamid': '76561198425378972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 910, 'last_played': 1676094041}
review: This has been a really enjoyable game that captures some of that HeroQuest nostalgia but showcases a unique appeal in its own right. It is fairly short, even with a second play through on hardcore mode. However, this seems to fit the nature of the game, and I believe it is still worth the $8 price tag. I do have to give a strong warning that this game is not without its bugs/glitches. Multiplayer can be troublesome to initiate (but this is how I played the whole game and I think the actually gameplay shines in multiplayer!!). Exiting rooms and accessing stairs can cause the game to lock up. Also, do not plan to play this game with four people as very few missions actually allow four player. Most are limited to two or three players and there are a few solo missions. Overall, I had a blast playing through this game with my friends! I am hoping there are plans for a Dark Quest 3 in the works!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991107884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1567715755}
review:
Alors pour ma part, j'ai achet√© le jeu vers 21h et je l'ai fini a 2h00 du matin....
Je pensais au moins trouver des cartes all√©atoires avec un system de difficult√©es plus ou moins grande en avancant.
En faite, plus on d√©bloque de sorts et plus le jeu devient facile malgr√©s les ennemis grandissant... 

La m√©canique du jeu rappels le jeu de plateau de H√©ros Quest des ann√©es 90 avec des plus...
Bon pour le prix on est pas vol√©, le jeu est bon mais bien trop court.... Ce jeu devrait proposer assez de map pour tenir un joueurs acharn√©e comme moi pendant au moins un bon mois.

Le jeu propose un √©diteur de map et de partage, mais la communaut√©e √† l'air assez pauvre.  
Je n'ai rencontr√© qu'un bug ou un personnage est rest√© bloqu√© lorsque j'ai mont√© un escalier. j'ai du abandonn√© la partie. sinon rien de f√¢cheux. 

Des maps add-on avec contenue multiplier par 20 serait la bienvenue.... car en finissant le jeu, je m'attendais voir une suite avec plus de difficult√©es... Ce qui en fait vite un jeu vide d'interet!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008434983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1625099760}
review:
The art style and animations are charming. The dungeons and character abilities keep things interesting. I'm sure this was a labor of love for the devs and I feel that playing the game, too. For $8 it is a steal.
There are still quite a few annoyances: Accidentally leaving a dungeon before you are ready. Wizards being put in front of the party in a new room. The leveling system is weak towards the end of the game. Etc...

author: {'steamid': '76561198000959806', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1530468899}
review: When playing with a friend, you are forced to venture only as two players (instead of a party of 3-4). Weird thing to punish players for not playing solo
developer_response: You can still beat the game with 2 players if you play good but each player controls 1 hero in multiplayer

author: {'steamid': '76561198006722733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1529853934}
review: A very nice surprise, not expensive, and quite fun to play. If you enjoyed Darkest Dungeon, and want something a little more "light" or "casual", then Dark Quest 2 is the game to go. Less frustration than in Darkest Dungeon since you can revive your characters (except in Hardcore mode), but still pretty enjoyable with replay value. If you never played Darkest Dungeon though, I would suggest to go for it instead, since it is at the same price roughly, but more deep and more "hardcore".

author: {'steamid': '76561198033154477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1672764716}
review:
A lo mejor Dark Quest 2 solo resulta atractivo a los que hemos jugado al prehist√≥rico Hero Quest en sus diferentes versiones  -tablero, Spectrum, PC, etc. Las reglas y el concepto art√≠stico son tan similares que me pregunto si no han tenido problemas con el copyright.
Para los que no conozcan el sistema de juego, ah√≠ va un resumen -la verdad es que es tan simple que tampoco hay mucho que resumir:
-Hay una campa√±a con mapas predise√±ados formados por cuadriculas y con tan solo unos cuantos elementos con los que interactuar. Que yo recuerde: puertas, pasajes "ocultos" -en realidad muy visibles- palancas, tesoros, trampas, objetos valiosos y una docena de tipos de monstruos.
-Para completar las misiones cuentas con un n√∫mero de jugadores que est√° predeterminado para cada mapa -entre 1 y 6. Los personajes son predise√±ados: b√°rbaro, palad√≠n, enano, mago, monje y arquero.
-En cada mapa hay una cantidad fija de botellas azules que son lo que m√°s merece la pena esforzarse en conseguir porque sirven para aprender habilidades nuevas o mejorarlas hasta tres niveles. Cada personaje tiene su conjunto de habilidades. Los mapas se pueden volver a jugar, pero las botellas no se regeneran. As√≠ que solo merece la pena repetirlos si necesitas dinero o te has dejado alguna botella sin coger.
-El otro modo de "personalizar" a tus h√©roes es comprarles objetos y colocarlos en los dos huecos que tienen a tal efecto. Tambi√©n pueden llevar una o dos pociones. El n√∫mero de objetos es limitado y solo hay uno de cada clase. La parte estrat√©gica del juego est√° sobre todo en seleccionar para cada tipo de mapa el equipo de parsonajes adecuado con los objetos y pociones adecuadas.
-Los jugadores se mueven, cogen cosas, caen en est√∫pidas trampas, lanzan hechizos y dan y reciben -sobre todo esto √∫ltimo- mamporros y, adem√°s, caen en nuevas est√∫pidas trampas. Si se mueren pueden ser resucitados por un porcentaje de tu cash en ese momento -moraleja: compra muchas cosas antes de resucitar a alguien. Si tus personajes se rinden antes de terminar el mapa, pierden los objetos y la mitad del dinero que hubiesen conseguido en ese mapa -pero todo lo dem√°s queda intacto.
-El combate es como en Hero Quest. Hay un tanto por ciento de ataque al que se le resta un tanto por ciento de defensa. Si tienes √©xito, haces un punto de da√±o. Lo intentas tantas veces como puntos de ataque tengas. 

No he terminado todav√≠a la campa√±a, pero hasta ahora me est√° resultando f√°cil ¬°y que me resulte f√°cil a m√≠ es algo digno de notarse! Que yo sepa, no se puede salvar la partida dentro de un mapa -y digo salvar, sin m√°s, para dejarlo y luego seguir otro rato, no hablo de esa delicatessen para mi paladar degenerado, que es el savescum con Voll Damm.
Todo esta emocionante aventura se desarrolla en unos preciosos cuartitos isom√©tricos, que a m√≠ por lo menos me encantan y me ponen nost√°lgico. Vamos, el apartado art√≠stico, es de lo que m√°s me gusta.
Algunas pegas -aparte de lo de no poder salvar y continuar en medio de un mapa:
-Los mu√±ecos son tan grandes que a veces resulta complicado hacer click en tal o cual parte, porque la est√°n tapando. 
-Las trampas. No les veo la gracia. Tampoco se la ve√≠a en el juego de tablero.
-Se hace corto. Hay un editor y mapas en Workshop pero no los he probado. A m√≠ me parece que los autores deber√≠an haber inclu√≠do por lo menos cuatro o cinco campa√±as m√°s, o alg√∫n tipo de modalidad con mapas aleatorios. Tambi√©n es verdad que los skills de los personajes no dan mucho de s√≠. Enseguida tienes al m√°ximo los que m√°s te interesan.
-Los personajes dir√≠a que est√°n un poco desequilibrados: el arquero y el mago me parecen muy flojos, y el monje es un megaOP (no dud√©is en reclutarlo enseguida y en gastar en √©l las botellas azules).

Bueno ¬øy qu√©? ¬øRecomendable? ¬°Por supuesto! Os har√° pasar dos o tres buenas tardes. Y tendr√° sus fallos, pero es un Hero Quest. Es decir:  ser√° una mierda pero es nuestra mierda.

EDIT: Se me ha olvidado decir que tiene modo multijugador, pero como no lo he probado, pues...

author: {'steamid': '76561198164310371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1527821939}
review:
I only played through this game once.

I noticed that it was easy to play through the second level several times to get 4 skill potions per run if you just surrender the dungeon instead of completing it. Suggestion: Make it so that you could only replay levels for the first, second... time after completing the entire game once, twice, etc.

I found that the logical choice was to use the Dark Monk and the Dwarf up until the chaos levels, at which point it was necessary to swap out the Dwarf for the Knight. I chose to use the Archer as my third character, but I feel the difficulty of the game would be about the same using either Barbarian or Wizard in place of the Archer.

The inability to walk to squares that you could not see because of the camera angle was annoying.

There should be a keyboard shortcut to toggle "confirm moves", it would be nice to be able to change it without having to go into the menu.

There were some weird glitches, but that did not detract from my overall enjoyment of this game. I'll admit that I got pretty into this game for a couple of weeks, but there is not that much to it.

In my opinion, the highlight of this game is playing with the Dark Monk. Its abilities are all pretty fun, and its even more fun with the Staff of Teleportation. I enjoyed using Chaos Wave to do tons of damage, and using Friends from the Past to buddy up with your enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020313592', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 576, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1526854780}
review:
[h1] Review - Dark Quest 2 [/h1]
This review was brought you by [url=www.saveorquit.com]Save Or Quit![/url], visit us!

===

[h1] RATING: 7.0 / 10 - Fantasy Adventure 101 [/h1] 

===

[h1] Overview [/h1]
Dark Quest 2 is a turn-based RPG dungeon crawler. The storyline kicks of in one of the most classical ways: the king is dead, an evil sorcerer seized the castle and his horde of minions is ravaging the lands, bringing death and destruction. Only a handful of valiant heroes are left, and theygather in the last free city of the kingdom, where an Elder will task them with various quests aimed to destroy the enemy forces and save the land. Even if the story is quite the fantasy stereotype, it isn't so bad. You will then be placed in command of a party of maximum four heroes, chosen by a pool of six, each with their own abilities and attack types, other than different values for passive traits such as Perception, fear resistance, or chance to parry an attack. The combat is turn-based and not very complex at that, but does the job and provides even a good challenge in some levels.

===

[h1] Gameplay Analysis [/h1]



[b] General Gameplay [/b]
In Dark Quest II you will have to manage a company of heroes in their quest against the Sorcerer. To do this, you have an entire city at your disposal with different functions: a blacksmith will forge you new gear to give to your heroes, for a price in gold. Some pieces of gear only can be given to specific heroes, some others to anyone. These pieces of gear will have different effects, such as more movement points per turn, more damage per attack, inflicting damage on enemies that attack you, or more uses for spells, and more. Each hero can equip maximum two gear pieces. Then you have the Alchemist, selling powerful potions to aid you in combat, such as health regen, refresh abilities to use them again, damage reduction and so on. Also in this case, two maximum per hero, except the Monk, he can carry only one.

The other facilities in the city are Gravedigger, can resurrect dead heroes for 20% of your gold in exchange, Taver, heroes can rest there to regain full HP, 50 gold each, the Brothel, where your heroes not only can have some fun but also receive a random bonus in their next level, and finally the Merchant where you can sell items you find in dungeons such as jewels and gems, for gold.

The campaign levels are articulated in a map, finishing a level will unlock all the ones linked to it, some levels are special rooms filled with treasure, but are on the edges of the map and difficult sections are before them. Each level has a set number of heroes that can partecipate, not always four, but often three or two heroes are maximum, forcing you to make difficult choices for party composition. Campaign missions are quite varied and provide a good number of different enemies, situations and objectives, like liberating prisoners, collecting pieces of an artifact, or killing a boss. 

Each hero has a dedicated skill tree with unique abilities, they can be upgraded by finding Blue Potions in levels, each level has a set number of them, plus a bonus one awarded for defeating all enemies. Other than skills, heroes also possess attributes, which are Courage, Sanity and Perception, all used to pass skill checks in specific situations or resist enemy effects: for example Perception is used when looting corpses or avoiding traps, while Courage is used to resist Fear spells. Some items can enhanche attributes slightly. 

If all your heroes die you get nothing from a level, while Retreating gives you 50% of the gold you gained and you can keep all the blue potions, so escaping can always be an option if things are looking grim. The fact you can repeat a level any number of times to accumulate blue potions and gold is good on one side, so you can level all your heroes enough to overcome more difficult levels, but on the other it's rather boring having to do the same level a lot of times to get enough potions to upgrade all heroes to their best.


[b] Combat System [/b]
Combat in Dark Quest II is turn-based, each character has one movement action, one attack action, and one skill action per turn, and so do enemies. Damage types are Physical, Magic and Chaos. The first two can be avoided respectively by parrying or evading, with anti-magic shields or special protection skills, while Chaos damage is unavoidable in all cases save for the Priest's barrier spell.

Bear in mind each enemy has a different percetange of scoring a melee or ranged hit, damage values, damage type, parry chance, all these things can be seen by hovering on an enemy and must be taken into account to choose the right hero for the right situation. A balanced team composition with support characters, frontline melee and also distance fighters will be paramount for success, as enemies will become a lot tougher in the later stages of the game.

Overall, the combat of Dark Quest II may not be complex like some other turn-based RPGs, and sometimes i found it a bit too tied to RNG, but still can provide fun and is overall well balanced and works alright.



[b] Content [/b]
It took me around 7 hours to finish all levels. Other than the campaign, a level editor is available to share custom levels on the Steam Workshop and download other players' creations, a nice addition, but with a quite complex and professional-looking editor that needs dedication to learn.


[b] Balancing [/b]
I found all classes and enemies to be fairly well balanced, with no particular things standing out as broken or underpowered.


[b] Challenge [/b]
This game can provide a decent challenge and is engaging enough.


===

[h1] Technical Analysis [/h1]



[b] Graphics [/b]
The hand drawn 2D style has its charm, and while animations in cinematics are a bit wonky and weird, overall the art style is good and different from what we're used to see around, it's a nice depiction of a grim fantasy world. Don't expect modern effects and graphics, since everything is hand drawn with 2D sprites.


[b] Sound [/b]
An average sound compartment with no particular things standing out.


[b] Performance [/b]
Nothing to report, should run on a toaster.


[b] Stability [/b]
Nothing to report.


[b] AI [/b]
Enemy AI is decent, only problem with it is that enemies will always attack the character nearest to them, doesn't matter if some other character is more vulnerable, they always attack the closest. This can be taken advantage of.

[b] Quality of Life [/b]
Some things could use a rework, like showing in the quest map how many Blue Potions each level cotains without having to enter that level, same for gold and enemy number. There should be an option to better select character when they are covered by enemy models, as many times it happened that my characters were very hard to control because overlapped by enemy models.


[b] Bugs / Issues [/b]
Nothing to report.

===

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Dark Quest II is a rather basic but satisfying turn based dungeon crawler that can give out some hours of fun at a budget price. The editor has potential and is definitely a nice addition. I'd say if you like turn-based and want something a bit different, try this.

review:

Ka≈æd√° mise sest√°v√° z relativnƒõ kr√°tk√©ho dungeonu, ve kter√©m v√°s ƒçekaj√≠ nep≈ô√°tel√©, pasti, ale tak√© poklady. Ka≈æd√° v√°m zabere od 10-ti do 40-ti minut. P≈ô√≠bƒõh zde hraje druh√© housle a v√≠cem√©nƒõ ho ani nebudete registrovat, RPG prvky jsou vcelku o≈ôezan√©, ale dungeony jsou kr√°sn√©, souboje jsou zaj√≠mav√© a r≈Øzn√© kombinace hrdin≈Ø p≈ôedev≈°√≠m s velmi rozd√≠ln√Ωmi speci√°ln√≠mi schopnostmi v vyb√≠zej√≠ k jin√© taktice. Velmi jinak se bojuje v otev≈ôen√Ωch prostor√°ch pln√Ωch past√≠, kde nav√≠c ƒçel√≠te p≈ôesile, nebo na √∫zk√© cestiƒçce.

Abych ale jen nechv√°lil, nƒõkolik v√Ωtek m√°m. Nƒõkter√© vƒõci by st√°ly za bli≈æ≈°√≠ vysvƒõtlen√≠, p≈ô√≠kladnƒõ u p√°r speci√°ln√≠ch schopnost√≠ zjist√≠te jak funguj√≠ a≈æ pot√©, co si je po≈ô√≠d√≠te, proto≈æe jsou opravdu... no prostƒõ speci√°ln√≠. Velk√Ω neduh je nedo≈ôe≈°en√© chozen√≠ vypl√Ωvaj√≠c√≠ z izometrick√©ho pohledu. Pokud chci jednou postaviƒçkou j√≠t na pol√≠ƒçko, kter√© je v z√°krytu jin√© postaviƒçky, tak je to skoro ne≈ôe≈°iteln√©. To sam√©, kdy≈æ na to pol√≠ƒçko chci d√°t t≈ôeba past. V podstatƒõ se mus√≠m s t√≠m, kdo zavaz√≠, pohnout jinam, ƒç√≠m≈æ samoz≈ôejmƒõ ztrat√≠m 1 pohyb. Mo≈æn√° to je ≈ôe≈°en√© nƒõjak√Ωm ovl√°dac√≠m tlaƒç√≠tkem, ale to by musel b√Ωt nƒõkde seznam ovl√°dac√≠ch kl√°ves. Dvakr√°t se mi stalo, ≈æe AI zm√°tlo, kdy≈æ jsem postavil s trpasl√≠kem nep≈ô√°tel≈Øm do cesty sud s ostny (spec. schopnost na odl√°k√°n√≠ pozornosti), nep≈ô√°tel√© z≈Østali st√°t na m√≠stƒõ a m√≠sto toho, aby sud rozbili, se nechali ust≈ô√≠let moj√≠ lukost≈ôelkyn√≠. Bav√≠me se ale o 2 m√≠stnostech za hru... 

≈Ωe hra nevznikala se z√°vratn√Ωm rozpoƒçtem je asi z≈ôejm√© hned, nicm√©nƒõ bavil jsem se po celou dobu (12 hodin na st≈ôedn√≠ obt√≠≈ænost) velmi dob≈ôe. Za mƒõ 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970217405', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1527806784}
review: This is a very nice looking Heroquest style game that is well presented. Starts off fun, but then quickly becomes impossible it seems. Unless I am doing something very wrong, after the 3rd map the odds seem very unfairly stacked against you. 3 members in my party and any room with 3/4 or more enemies will wipe my party out. My fighters dont hit often nor does my archer. enemies nearly always hit.  So it doesnt seem possible to level my party up at all.
developer_response:
You can ask in the forums for some help instead of leaving a negative review. The game is not that hard, if you are not carefull it will result in a party wipe out though. You can find some guides in the forums to see how to improve your experience.

With that said here are some quick tips:
- Try to make it to the bonus room quest which will yield lots of treasure.
- Start over in easy mode and use some of your experience to make better decisions.
- Get multiple level 1 skills in the begining.

- Go for barbarian, dwarf, wizard 

- Barbarian(get rage, counterattack and double attack passives)

- Wizard(lighting bolt, inferno, illusions)

- Dwarf (detect traps level and disarm trap level2 + barrel block)

These are good starting points

author: {'steamid': '76561198003181303', 'num_games_owned': 418, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2038, 'last_played': 1561608310}
review:
I'm loving this game.

I'm only about half-way through this game (and played some Custom Maps), and I am already hoping for new content (like another DLC campaign).

I got this to play a co-op, turn-based, fantasy RPG with my friend, and it has been super addictive. I think I would compare it to Warhammer Quest as far as similarity in game because I've never played Hero Quest.

After the tutorial, you start out in the Village. Generally, you choose a group of your characters for a certain quest, swap out any items you want assigned to each character, make sure the characters have the potion types they may want, and select the quest (you usually have a choice of quests, and they get harder each time you repeat them, so it's good to advance the campaign).

Once in the quest, each character takes a turn by moving, using a skill, using a potion, and attacking. Then the monsters get to do the same to you. There are variables and twists that can alter the core turn, but that is the basic sequence. It's pretty easy to learn, and it gets levels of complexities added to keep it challenging.

There are some great guides out there for the game and the map editor (I'm excited about creating my own maps).

author: {'steamid': '76561198039570003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1379, 'last_played': 1594523742}
review: Great game! I played it for a whole day straight and beat it on Normal...now onto Hardcore mode. Challenging and thoughtful, Dark Quest 2 is exactaly what I want in a turn based dungeon crawler/strategy game. I wish there was a multi-player "dungeon finder" kind of function though. Impossible to play multi-player unless you have friends that play it. I reccomend this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024267821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1534559719}
review:
Great game! only gripe is as follows:

No transparency or easy way to select heroes/treasure/enemies when alot is in the room.  Also, there is no confirm quit feature.  If you accidently (i misclicked) and lost all progress for one area.

Pros:

Great turn based game
Fast paced (depending on your walking speed setting)
No bugs i have found so far in the campaign (just smashed the orc army)
You can replay most levels (except bonus room) with higher difficulty if you need to level a new hero/grind
Really enjoyed certain levels where you had to fight alot of enemies.  Was fun to strategize on spell/skill usage and to implement my team build to defeat the room.

All in all this is more than worth the asking price if you like turn based dungeon stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009995982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1523899636}
review:
Worth every buck invested.
This feels like Darkest dungeon, without the anguish and frustration associated to it.
An less replay value, obviously. Still, a very good old school dungeon crawler.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142425910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1524171697}
review:
Highly recommend if you enjoy turn-based dungeon crawls. Can't recommend highly enough, actually.

A great game that has me wishing for more. The design is simple and fun. I've never actually played Hero Quest, but I've played IOS versions of the Warhammer equivalent, and this game definietly scratches that itch -- far better in many ways. 

The dungeons are not proceduraly generated, they're each hand-crafted and it benefits from this greatly. The fights, encounters and challenges continue to feel fresh and different. 

The playable characters are fun and each have their own strengths. There are a few options to pick from (six) and you usually crawl with three at a time. 

The game is not deep but playing it, I wish it were. I want more, which I guess is the hallmark of a good game with a solid design. 

I plan to pick up Dark Quest 1, the original, to just measure the changes made (just looking, the visuals are a big improvement) and to support these devs, they deserve it. Hopefully they're working on Dark Quest 3, with it hopefully having the same enjoyability and more depth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064901782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1539165968}
review:
If you have ever played Hero Quest the boardgame, this game will feel very familiar..

The good:
The art is really nice. 
The music and sound is good.
Feels like an oldschool dungeoncrawler.
6 character classes with few, but pretty interesting skills and items.

The bad:
Some people complain about the UI, but I really have no problems with it..

Another thing is when you need to backtrack to a room you missed, 
and have to walk each individual character through all the rooms area transitions.. it takes a bit of time.
It kind of feels the same as a DM in a game like Hero Quest, who do not want your party to jump to the end, 
but want you to roll dice for every move to get to the staircase, even if there are no enemies on the board.
I have no major problem with that either.. 

I have played a few hours, unlocked all characters, but not finished the game yet.
It does not seem that long, but it might be a game that is enjoyable to try to beat on hardcore,
and something you can just jump into to take a couple of dungeons when you have some spare time.

It is not the most complicated game, but it has enough there to be enjoyable
and the price is on point, so yeah I recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972907112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1561036903}
review: Very solid RPG for the price. 6 recruitable heroes, interesting skills that allow you to do great combos. Enemies are stronger as you progress the game and their behavior decent. Graphic style is fitting the narrative of the game and you will really feel like you are in the story, in the dungeon. That being sad, the game is nothing inovative or groundbreaking, but fine RPG for easy times. Dont get me wrojng, it can still punish you plenty, but the challenge is on "okay" level

author: {'steamid': '76561198273254344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1523552903}
review:
Well, it's relatively short, but I really enjoyed it. I appreciate that of all the "Hero Quest clones" I've played in the last year or so, this one seems to have incorporated the most new, fresh ideas. I especially liked the Dark Monk, even though he seemed slightly overpowered. That's probably why though, lol.

The main thing I didn't like is that you only get 3 heroes for most maps, and you only get to use 4 once in the whole game! I would strongly have preferred to use 4 on most maps.

review:
Nos¬≠t¬≠al¬≠gi¬≠ker werden sich freuen. Hero Quest l√§sst gr√º√üen. Auf Normal nimmt der Schwierigkeitsgrad bei ein paar Missionen am Ende geh√∂rig zu. Es lohnt sich √§ltere Missionen zu wiederholen um zus√§tzliche Phiolen zu bekommen. Mit diesen kann man die F√§higkeiten der Charaktere  steigern. Da steckt auch der gro√üe Reiz im Spiel.
 Toll ist es die unterschiedlichen Vor und Nachteile der 6 Charaktere aus zu probieren. Je nach Mission muss man switchen. 
Die Musik im Hintergrund ist sehr sch√∂n und passt immer gut in die Szenerie. Grafik geht voll in Ordnung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055838774', 'num_games_owned': 1303, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 493, 'last_played': 1521021813}
review:
[h1]Ein klassischer Dungeon-Crawler[/h1]
Befreie das Dorf aus den F√§ngen des b√∂sen Hexers und seiner Untertanen, in einem klassischen Dungeon-Crawler. Inspiriert von dem Brettspiel Hero Quest.

[table]
[tr]

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/-German_Gamer_Community-#curation] [i]Diese Review wurde durch das Kuratorprogramm der GGC zur Verf√ºgung gestellt[/i] [/url]

[h1]Story [/h1]

[quote]Eines Nachts hielt der K√∂nig ein Fest in seiner Burg, bei dem Bewohner aus dem ganzen Reich gekommen waren. Doch die feierliche Nacht sollte ein j√§hes Ende finden.
Der Hexer lie√ü seine Schar an Orks und Goblins die Burg untertunneln und attackierte in dieser Nacht den K√∂nig. Es wurden Kreaturen aus anderen Dimensionen von dem Hexer beschworen und in wenigen Stunden wurden alle anwesenden, M√§nner, Frauen und sogar Kinder abgeschlachtet.
Die einzigen die es √ºberlebt haben waren jene die sich zu dieser Zeit im Dorf aufhielten. Doch dies bedeutet nicht, dass sie verschont von dieser Grausamkeit waren. Seit dem Sturz des K√∂nigs durch den Hexer werden die Bewohner des Dorfes geplagt durch die Schreie der Gefallenen.
Deine Aufgabe ist es die Burg zu betreten und den Wahnsinn, Horror und Tot gegen√ºberzutreten, sowie schlussendlich das Reich aus den F√§ngen des b√∂sen Hexers und seiner Untertanen zu befreien.[/quote]


[h1]Gameplay [/h1]

[b]Dark Quest 2[/b] ist die zweite Anlehnung des Studios [i]Brain Seal Ltd[/i] an das 1989 erschienene Brettspiel [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/699/heroquest]HeroQuest[/url]. 
Der Aufbau des Spiels ist recht simpel. In jedem Level erforscht der Spieler mit seiner Gruppe von Helden ein Dungeon, diese werden nicht zuf√§llig generiert, anders als gew√∂hnlich f√ºr Dungeon-Crawler. Die Level sind klassisch zweidimensional, wie man es von Brettspielen gewohnt ist, und bestehen aus quadratischen Feldern. Die Gruppengr√∂√üe variiert von 1 bis zu 4 Helden und der Spieler kann aus sechs unterschiedlichen Helden sein Team zusammenstellen.
Ziel in dem Level ist es den Ausgang bzw. die gefragte Quest (z.B. finde das Artefakt oder T√∂te jenen) abzuschlie√üen. Zus√§tzlich l√§sst sich immer Gold und eine feste Anzahl an magischen Tr√§nken im jedem Level finden, sofern ihr alle Gegner besiegt habt droppt der letzte Gegner einen weiteren magischen Trank. Mit diesen magischen Tr√§nken ist es im Dorf dann m√∂glich die F√§higkeiten der Helden zu verbessern.
Wie gewohnt k√∂nnen mit dem Gold Tr√§nke gekauft werden (keine magischen Tr√§nke), sowie neue Ausr√ºstung, ein Bett in der Taverne gemietet werden um die Helden zu heilen, Helden von Friedhof wiederbeleben oder Leistungen im Bordell erhalten f√ºr Bonus-Stats im n√§chsten Level.
Die Kampagne kann in drei Schwierigkeitsstufen (Einfach, Normal & Hardcore) gespielt werden. Dabei steigt der Schwierigkeitsgrad von Normal auf Hardcore enorm an, da es im Hardcore-Modus nicht mehr die M√∂glichkeit vorhanden ist gefallene Kameraden nach dem Abschluss des Levels wiederzubeleben.  Dennoch ist das Kampfsystem sehr linear und sofern das Spiel schon auf einem niedrigeren Schwierigkeitsgrad durchgespielt wurde ist die Herausforderung auch eher geringer.
Des Weiteren l√§sst die ganze Kampagne im Mehrspielermodus mit bis zu 4 Freunden spielen.
Zus√§tzlich zu der Kampagne ist ein Map-Editor vorhanden. Mit diesen kann jeder eigene Level entwerfen und sp√§ter in den Steam Workshop hochladen, damit auch andere diese ausprobieren k√∂nnen.


[h1]Grafik[/h1]

Die Grafik in [b]Dark Quest 2[/b] ist handgezeichnet und besitzt eine gewisse Tiefe an Detail. Durch den eigenen Stil wird das Setting au√üerhalb der Level, im Dorf und Cutszenen, sehr gut vermittelt. W√§hrend im Dorf eine ziemlich d√ºstere Stimmung vorherrscht, sind die Level innerhalb der Burg sehr stark beleuchtet. Die Stimmung geht dadurch leider zum gro√üen Teil verloren, jedoch f√ºr den spielerischen Aspekt, dass der Spieler alles erkennen kann, ist es besser.
Die Kamera ist auf einen Blickwinkel beschr√§nkt und kann in gr√∂√üeren R√§umen nur in der Ebene verschoben werden. Das Blickfenster wird umrandet mit raumspezifischen Baumaterialien, so schaut der Spieler im Verlie√ü durch Holzbalken, w√§hrend dieser in der Burg durch ein Loch in Decke/Wand die Geschehnisse beobachtet.  Ein Problem hat diese Sicht. Oftmals blockieren die eigenen Charaktere mehrere Felder und m√ºssen oftmals neu positioniert werden damit man wieder auf den Ausgang des Raumes klicken kann, dasselbe Problem st√∂rt auch ab und an in K√§mpfen, dennoch gew√∂hnt man sich relativ z√ºgig daran und lernt darum zu spielen.  
Die Level m√∂gen einen zweidimensionalen Aufbau haben, so sind jedoch die Charaktere und Gegner vollkommen dreidimensional modelliert. Die Charaktere und Gegner sehen sehr passend aus. Leider m√ºssen Abz√ºge im Charakterdesign gemacht werden, da ausger√ºstete Gegenst√§nde sich nicht auf das Aussehen des jeweiligen Charakters auswirken.


[h1]Musik [/h1]

Die Musik ist authentisch und vermittelt einer der Situation entsprechende Stimmung. Insgesamt ist eher ein ruhigerer Stil der zu dem Spielprinzip passt, dabei pendelt die Melodie sie startet langsam mit ein paar Elementen und steigert im Verlauf die Soundelemente bis zu einem gewissen Punkt und wird dann wieder weniger. 
Die Soundeffekte f√ºr K√§mpfe oder f√ºr die Stadt sind sehr gut gew√§hlt worden, doch bieten sie keine Abwechslung und so h√∂rt man vor allem beim Kampf immer aufs Neue dieselben Sounds z.B. wenn ein Angriff geblockt wird.


[h1]Pers√∂nliches Fazit [/h1]

[b]Dark Quest 2[/b] ist ein solides RTS-Spiel. Es hat zwar seine Ecke und Kanten mit dem linearen Kampfsystem und eingeschr√§nkten Blickwinkel, dennoch √§ndert dies kaum etwas an dem Spielspa√ü. F√ºr 7,99 ‚Ç¨ erh√§lt man ein qualitativ angemessenes Spiel mit einer groben Kampagnenspielzeit von 6 Stunden, mit der zus√§tzlichen M√∂glichkeit eigene Level zu entwerfen und zu spielen.  

[b]Eine gelungene √úberf√ºhrung eines Brettspiels auf den PC[/b]

[i]Wenn euch diese Review zusagt folgt gerne unserem [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/-German_Gamer_Community-#curation] Reviewprogramm [/url].[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198018345646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1551904454}
review:
Dark Quest 2 is good fun for its price. Especially since you can play multiplayer co-op with friends. Too many board games forget the importance of this.

The atmosphere and music are great.

All it needs is deeper character building, customization and equipment systems for better replayability. And the UI could be improved.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141167939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1520706460}
review:
The game is a good old fashioned dungeon crawl, clearly inspired by Hero Quest but with references to other games as well (the blue potions look like Golden Axe, and there are Diablo references here and there as well).

Each level you have to select a small number of fighters, 3 for the most part of the game, which forces you to plan ahead carefully. If, for instance, you pick Barbarian (Melee DPS) and Knight (Tank/Healer) you have to decide whether you want a ranged attacker (Archer), a trap spotter (Dwarf) or a magic user (Wizard). You can also carry a limited number of potions. Different teams may lead to very different approach to the level.

The interface is not the best, but unless you are using a controller we are not talking of something that makes the game unplayable, in fact you get used to it quite quickly.

I finished the game at normal difficulty in about a day of play (taking pauses) so it's not particularly long. While levels can be re-played, this probably makes more sense in co-op. Hopefully new levels, and new classes, will add some life to a game that is overall very fun and pleasant.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065091371', 'num_games_owned': 87, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1603104625}
review: would like a hot-seat multiplayer

author: {'steamid': '76561198286017559', 'num_games_owned': 2641, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1520625972}
review:
So, with a bland name like Dark Quest, is the game itself also bland, or is it actually fun? Considering how both the setting and the characters look and act, they are quite generic, but Dark Quest 2 as a turn-based RPG is actually quite fun and interesting.

The game puts you in control of up to three heroes, which need to defeat an evil sorcerer. Featuring an amazing, hand-drawn isometric art style and dice-based mechanics, Dark Quest 2 really looks like a board game that came to life in a digital form.

Every map is made to question the strength, courage, and sanity of your party, so make sure you come prepared. Besides the challenging single player mode, Dark Quest 2 even features a multiplayer mode, where players can either play together to try to defeat the evil sorcerer or they can just go to the arena and try to kill each other.

We don't see many turn-based dungeon crawlers these days, but Dark Quest 2 definitely looks promising. The game is in Early Access at the moment, but it's quite packed with content which should keep you entertained at least for a little while!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970799950', 'num_games_owned': 1071, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1547402734}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994750031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1569986452}
review:
This game is awesome. It mixes the classic dungeon and classic rules of dungeon games of the past in with a supurb modernization that most nastalga remakes completely miss.

Add in Co-Op, and good humor and you're looking at an ultra fine dungeon crawl developed exactly how you dreamed the future would be when you were a kid on your 386,  if FPS haddn't taken over gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092142580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1520702619}
review:
By the time of writing this, I have put about 5 hours into this game. If you like roguelike combined with turn-based game play, you might very well enjoy this game. The graphics and game play are very nostalgic and appealing. It's the type of game that hooked me instantly. And I look forward to putting more time into it.

There is one glaring issue I've encountered while playing and that is that you are unable to rotate the camera. It can make it difficult to pick up items, choose the correct opponent, take the right path and causes some frustration when you're trying to do one thing and you end up accidentally doing another. I hope at some point in the future a rotate feature is included in the game but I don't think it's such a huge issue that it should prevent you from enjoying the game play experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042235490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1587665846}
review: The game is pretty fun, but a little lacking in content.  It doesnt take long to max out a heros' skill and the crafting is fairly limited.  Also, when playing 2 person multiplayer, you should be able to bring more than 1 person on a 3-4 player quest.  All in all, the game has potential.  If updated with more quests and a more engaging story this could be a pretty amazing game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968907104', 'num_games_owned': 1058, 'num_reviews': 208, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1520423178}
review:
[b]tl;dr:[/b] Potentially fun casual turn-based game, ruined by offensively bad UI and controls.

WARNING: Quite the wall of text incoming.

[b]The good:[/b] 

First of all, if you are looking for a tactical challenge rivaling X-COM or Battle Brothers, look somewhere else.
What we have here is a rather simple and casual turn-based game with some light RPG attached to it.
Not every game has to be super hard and complex, so this isn't a downside to me.

You are in control of a bunch of heroes, of which you can take a number with you on each dungeon.
Dungeons are relatively short (I don't think you'll need more than 15 or 20 minutes for each) and filled with traps to step into, monsters to fight and lots of loot to find.

Graphics and sound are adequate, if a bit too cartoonish for my taste. It does fit the cheesy tone, though.

While casual, it isn't fully mindless, you actually have to make sure not to do really dumb moves that would get your characters killed and have to make good use of your abilities - as well as try to send a well-rounded team.
That said, the game is on the easy side of things and I very much recommend playing on Hardcore, or at the very least Normal. Easy will most likely put you into sleep.

As you progress through the game, more heroes will be unlocked, items can be bought and found magic potions are used to increase abilities and skills of your heroes.

I'd say it would be a fun little casual turn-based RPG to be played in small sessions or on the side.


Unfortunately, the game has such significant [b]downsides[/b] that make enjoying it almost impossible:

The UI and controls must have been designed with maximum waste of time in mind.
I have no other explanation for the things I will list now:

There are no hotkeys. I kid you not. 2018 and someone releases a turn-based tactical RPG without any hotkeys at all. ESC does not open the menu, nor does it close open menus. Tab opens no inventory or map, neither does M or I. Space or Enter does not end your turn. Everything requires moving the mouse around. It is a mind-boggling waste of time.

No minimap, either. And the map that is there opens not focused on your current location so you have to scroll around each time to find your room. What a waste of time, again.

Leaving a section of the dungeon requirew you to move every single one of your heroes to the exit manually. Every time, each section. When having four heroes with you, that means clicking eight times (!!!!) to leave an area. I would somewhat understand this, if the game allowed you to split your group, but that's not even possible. The developers obviously didn't care to have any kind of different logic attached for singleplayer vs co-op. A baffling waste of a player's time. 

Menus in the town are their own version of "how to waste the maximum amount of time of my players".
Is your idea of a good level-up interface to drag-and-drop a UI element onto a skill in order to improve it, instead of just clicking the ability?
Do you like having to drag-and-drop hero portraits around to rest, instead of clicking on them or - even better - having them auto-selected as there is no thinking involved in selecting them anyway?
Just how much do you love having to repeat "click sex worker, select menu, drag-and-drop a SINGLE hero, confirm" for every hero you want to receive a temporary bonus, despite the fact that other menus at least offer multiple slots to drag multiple heroes into?
And don't you totally dig having to drag-and-drop heroes into the slots for a mission instead of auto-selecting or just clicking them?
If the answer to any of these is "no", then... well, bad luck.
I don't know if the logic behind this nonsense was "immersion", but a drag-and-drop action is not immersive, it as an utter waste of my time. 

The character that has the ability to uncover traps in an area around him will still gladly walk into them, if the move command was given before the trap was discovered. Brillant. If you like moving in mini-steps to waste your time a little.

Good luck clicking on anything to top-left to top of one of your characters. The sprites block the view, so clicking anything there is quite the hassle. This is solved by moving the character around so you are able to click, e.g. on the exit.

The cherry on top? No linux support despite using Unity. Obviously, a dual-boot or virtual machine to test-run the binaries would have been asking too much. At least it does run fine under Wine.

All of this gives off the impression that the last 30 years of game development never happened, the developer never played a PC game or what we have here is a weird mobile port. But the game isn't even available for mobile!
I have rarely been this dumbfounded by shortcomings in a game as much as here. All of these could have been avoided by anyone ever having played another PC game taking a look at it and saying "Uhm... you might want to change this".

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Should the horrible UI and controls ever be fixed (or rather, something decent be implemented in the first place), I'd actually recommend this. Until then, if you do not have a Gandhi-like patience for a game wasting your time without any need, avoid this.

And finally, dear developer, repeat after me:
I shall not waste a player's time. I shall not waste a player's time. I shall not waste a player's time. I shall not waste a player's time. I shall not waste a player's time. I shall not waste a player's time. I shall not waste a player's time. I shall not waste a player's time...

author: {'steamid': '76561197971040782', 'num_games_owned': 1038, 'num_reviews': 257, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1520727421}
review:
Good o fashion dungeon crawler with single player and co-op.  Upgrade weapons, visit the vendors, recruit hero's and pickup characters some of the dungeons.    
Note crafting is really stock item upgrades
The more you play the stronger your hero gets.   
More loot would be great but probably better detection skill bonus could effect that.   
Walking tutorial
The mod support for more maps adds great replay value
Would have loved more voice acting as the intro is really good
If you liked Hero Quest you'll love this

author: {'steamid': '76561198336861356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1518937368}
review:
linear, simplistic character progression (not even visual progression is offered).
hugely lacking in character customization. homogenous playstyles.
short campaign supplemented by hit-or-miss user designed content. 
empty town hub lacking personality.
lack of incentive for me to keep playing.

the tactical combat and art style have their charm, 
but the rest of the experience could only be summed up as vapid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134730614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 934, 'last_played': 1517601401}
review:
It's a good game for ¬£5, looks good and is fun to play.  Easy to complete once you max out a couple of characters out and find a party dynamic that works for you.  

Though, if I'm completely honest, the character development/level up/equipment improvement is poor; they tried to do something a little different, but unfortunately it doesn‚Äôt work.  The story is really quite bad as well, at no point did I feel engaged with what was going on, which is REALLY important if you re going to have a success dungeon crawl due to how monotonous they can get.

If they develop a third edition, I'd be happy to pay ¬£20 for it IF they create a proper narrative, better character development and less restrictive equipment choices.   There is SO much potential here, just needs somebody to create a better world and characters.  Put another way, if Warhammer Quest and Dark Quest merged into one super game, I‚Äôd be happy. Better still just ask Games Workshop for the rights to develop 1980s classic Hero Quest‚Ä¶

review: It's a typical 6-7 out of 10 game that still offers good fun for the money. Imagine Dungelot with several heroes which still does not offer deep enough tactical combat. Metagame is ok at best, not enough variety in equipment. If you are badly starved for Dungeon Crawlers with Tactical elements - go for it, otherwise look for something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007394070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2355, 'last_played': 1528475976}
review:
Excellent game but only for those which are into simple classic turn based rpgs. It is an enhanced board game version of Heroquest and with the Editor for own maps and the ability to play it with friends online it is worth its money.
Those players which expect a full price rpg with lots of content will be disapointed. Hopefully there will be expansions to enhance the gameplay further. It is almost bug free, has nice grafics for a low priced game and the music is fine. I recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116695676', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1525014176}
review: Love this game. It feels very retro in a good way. It not perfect yet it has a few bugs, like things not beeing shown or going to the next room an your monk loosing HP (only the monk), but its a fun game and if you like turn based games you should try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037434029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1585, 'last_played': 1544965027}
review:
Do you like HERO QUEST, the Milton Bradley board game from 1989? 

Do you like HERO QUEST, the Gremlin Interactive computerised adaptation of the board game from 1991?

Would you like to play HERO QUEST again, with your friends, on Steam, but with shiny new graphics and new music by the same composer as the original Gremlin game?

THEN DARK QUEST 2 IS FOR YOU! The best game ever made since HERO QUEST!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016122089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1514930290}
review: What a great classic dungeon crawling game old school.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035611765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2751, 'last_played': 1521378021}
review:
I think that this game could have a lot of potential if more content / variety was added.  For example, crafting is limited to stock items - no means for customization and once the available items have been crafted, that is it - no more.  I think the game description of 'crafting' is therefore a little misleading. It would also be more fun if monsters dropped some loot, or you could find the odd useful hidden item, rather than just gold / items to sell.

Monster types are limited to variations on Orcs, Goblins or the odd Chaos Warrior.  Traps and Secret doors are not really challenging - i.e, no 'search for' option.  The variety of room type is also limited, and quickly become tedious / boring.  What about some outdoor environmments?  Also carrying a  max of two potions?  Seriously?  Even the simpler, but more accurate homage to Heroquest 'Mighty Dungeons' (I have the tablet version) allows you to carry multiple potions.

I know it pays homage to the original Heroquest, but what about bringing in some of the concepts from the 'Advanced Heroquest' game? - this was more of a half-way house toward full AD&D and could be more fun, though I guess this would probably require a redesign in coding, though I am sure a few elements could still be added to enrich the game.

A plus point, however, is the availability of the workshop and user maps - some of these have been fun and more challenging than the main quest lines.

Note that I cannot comment on any networking issues, as I don't play multiplayer.

All in all 5/10 for me, though I do like it, it is just that it needs more.  I would recommend this, once finally released and out of EA, but only on sale, not at full price, at least not until further content / variety was added.  Obviously my comments are based on the EA version, but - it is the late EA and so should therefore be very close to the final product, baring the very last map.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970330814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1509195584}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971623455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1509287412}
review:
No es un juego que vaya a ganar ning√∫n premio, pero sin duda te mantendr√° entretenido unas cuantas tardes. Tiene un agradable regustillo a los a√±os 80, una jugabilidad adecuada (aunque en ocasiones el manejo de los personajes sea complicado debido a la perspectiva), y la dificultad es la correcta.

100% recomendado si lo pillas en rebajas, si eres un fan de los dungeon crawlers, o si echas de menos HeroQuest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043726774', 'num_games_owned': 1552, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1505526516}
review:
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Category[/th]
        [th]Points*[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
        [td]Controls are intuitive. It's a point-and-click board game. Difficulty comes from strategy behind how to approach enemies and avoid traps.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Content[/td]
        [td]5[/td]
        [td]The game has an overworld similar to Super Mario World and a common area in a village for purchasing supplies, healing, and hiring new party members. Each level (quest) is a series of rooms reminiscent of the Hero Quest board game and take a decent amount of time to get through. I only have a couple of hours in the game as of this review, but could imagine it taking a good 20 hours to complete. Online co-op is also present, but we had difficulties keeping connection and staying in synch.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
        [td]Graphics are better than what you would typically expect for a board game. Character and environmental artwork is nice, animation is fluid if somewhat stretchy looking. Overall the game looks nice.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Audio[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
        [td]The sound effects are nothing special, but the music is good. Some of the tracks remind me of Heimdall from the Sega CD days.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Re-Playability[/td]
        [td]5[/td]
        [td]Re-Playability is probably average at best, at least until multiplayer and Steam Workshop is fully functional.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Total[/td]
        [td]6.3[/td]
        [td]If you like table top RPGs a la Hero Quest or Dragon Strike, then give this game a go. However, if you want to do online co-op, hold off and keep an eye on its development.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

* Points are weighted by 35%, 25%, 20%, 10%, and 10% for gameplay, content, graphics, audio, and re-playability, respectively.

[table]
    [tr]
        [td]Bang-for-Buck[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
        [td]At it's current state I wouldn't pay more than $8 or $9 for it. When the game is finished then it's full asking price of $13 will be a good value.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Achievements[/td]
        [td]1[/td]
        [td]I can't give this a good score as one achievement is currently not attainable as it is for defeating a yet to be implemented enemy. Another achievement for getting 100k gold also is silly.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

author: {'steamid': '76561198022318021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1524892555}
review:
If you ever find yourself looking for that D&D or Pathfinder type game you could play with your friends online, then this game is definitely worth looking at. By far, this game's greatest strength is its co-op campaign. My friends and I took to this game almost instantly for its fantasy setting, turn-based combat, and online co-op. VERY few games fall into that category.

So, selling points on the game:
- online co-op campaign, easy to use invites through steam.
- very huge improvement from the first Dark Quest, I mean you can really appreciate the game so much more if you play or even look at the first one.
- very well done art, making for a very visually pleasing experience. 
- great tactical combat, but think more "board game" than actual D&D
- interesting characters, 7 total at this time...looks like there might be room for 3 more?
- persistency between maps, you keep equipment, potions, gold and whatnot, interact with the village. 
- great replayability, the maps increase in difficulty after you beat them, so replaying actually does provide a challenge.
- super cheap for the hours of playtime you'll get!
- simple but effective story. Bad sorceror in giant castle torments the town, and he has an army of goblins, orcs, and undead. What more do you need here?

Cons:
- there are a few bugs here and there, it's Early Access
- sometimes, you'll find yourself wishing for more (like, dang I wish there were more characters, dang I wish we could further customize these characters, or dang I wish my equipment showed up on my character) but remember, it's Early Access
- you have to start with only the Barbarian and the Mage, then beat the first 5 levels if you wanted a specific other character (Devs if you're reading this, can we pick our starting heroes please?) but once again, Early Access!

In summary, all of the (admittedly minor) faults I found in this game, I was able to forgive because it is absolutely charming, super fun to play with 2 more of your friends, and if something didn't work for whatever reason...I just found myself saying "Oh well it's Early Access".
I'll be creating an account on their forums soon to list the few bugs we found, and maybe highlight some areas where the game could easily gain some free points with players. But overall, I absolutely recommend this game. It's a real winner, and I love supporting hard-working indie devs just like this.
